questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-day history of low-grade fever and sore throat. This morning, she noticed a rash on his buttocks, hands, and feet. He does not have pruritus. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 123/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows oral vesicles. A photograph of the rash on the feet is shown. Which of the following is the most likely pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gingivostomatitis and pharyngitis due to herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) can present with fever, sore throat, and vesicular oral lesions. Although herpetic gingivostomatitis is not usually associated with a rash, HSV-1 infection can trigger erythema multiforme (EM). EM, which typically begins on the extremities before spreading to the palms and soles, can also present as a papulovesicular rash. However, EM also characteristically presents with target lesions, which are absent in this patient.
Image Description:

Multiple circular lesions with a central papule and raised edges (also called “target lesions”), surrounded by a lighter edematous area, are visible on the anterior aspect of the thighs.

This is the typical appearance of erythema multiforme.

B) INCORRECT:

The varicella-zoster virus causes chickenpox, which can present with fever, sore throat, and vesicular lesions on the skin as well as oral mucosa. However, the rash of chickenpox typically starts on the trunk and spreads to the face and scalp; the palms and soles are less commonly involved. Also, the lesions are very pruritic and have a polymorphous appearance because the different stages of development (macules, papules, vesicles, erosions, crusts) are seen simultaneously.
Image Description:

A diffuse rash is seen in various stages of lesion evolution (starry-sky appearance), with mainly ruptured vesicles and crusted erosions seen here.

These findings are typical for chickenpox.

C) CORRECT:

Coxsackie A virus can cause hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), which presents with a nonpruritic papulovesicular rash on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. Oral vesicles can easily rupture and cause painful ulcers. In some cases, the arms, legs, and buttocks are also affected. The illness is typically self-limiting. Coxsackie A virus can also cause pharyngitis and herpangina.

Unlike coxsackie A virus, coxsackie B virus does not cause oral or cutaneous disease. It instead causes acute myocarditis, pericarditis, and pleurodynia.

D) INCORRECT:

Rubella typically presents with fever, sore throat, and a rash. However, the rubella exanthem is maculopapular rather than vesicular and it typically begins on the face before spreading caudally with sparing of the palms and soles. Examination of the oral cavity can sometimes reveal palatal petechiae (Forchheimer spots) but oral vesicles would not be expected.
Image Description:

A nonconfluent, pink, maculopapular rash is visible across this infant's trunk and extremities.

E) INCORRECT:

Human herpesvirus 6 causes roseola infantum, which can present with fever, sore throat, and a nonpruritic rash that appears several days after the onset of fever. However, the rash is macular, not vesicular and typically begins only after cessation of fever, whereas this patient is still febrile. Moreover, the rash appears initially on the trunk; the involvement of palms and soles is rare. Examination of the oral cavity can sometimes reveal palatal papules (Nagayama spots) but oral vesicles would not be expected.
Image Description:

Photograph of a 1-year-old child with recent febrile illness

A patchy, nonpruritic, blanching, erythematous rash with macules and papules can be seen on the trunk and arms. Symptoms manifested one day after the fever resolved.

These features are consistent with roseola infantum.

F) INCORRECT:

In children, parvovirus B19 causes erythema infectiosum, which can present with fever, sore throat, and a nonpruritic rash that appears a few days after the onset of fever. However, the rash of erythema infectiosum is characterized by malar erythema (“slapped cheek” appearance), circumoral pallor, and lace-like or reticular lesions on the trunk. Neither vesicular lesions nor the involvement of palms and soles would be expected.
Image Description:

The cheeks are bright red (slapped-cheek rash) and a diffuse, red, confluent rash with macules and papules is visible over the body of this infant.

This is the characteristic cutaneous appearance of erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which is caused by infection with parvovirus B19.

G) INCORRECT:

Epstein-Barr virus causes infectious mononucleosis, which can present with fever, sore throat, and a rash that occurs either in response to the infection itself or following the administration of a penicillin antibiotic. However, the rash of infectious mononucleosis is maculopapular, not vesicular and appears initially on the trunk; the involvement of palms and soles is rare. Examination of the oral cavity can reveal exudative tonsillar enlargement and palatal petechiae but oral vesicles would not be expected.
Image Description:

Upper body of a patient with a pruritic rash associated with the administration of an aminopenicillin for suspected bacterial tonsillitis.

There is an erythematous, patchy, partly confluent, maculopapular rash.

This appearance is typical of an aminopenicillin-related rash, seen in patients with infectious mononucleosis.
questions.hint: A rash on the hands, feet, and mouth is typical of this pediatric febrile exanthem.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a progressive rash for 2 days. The rash started on the face and now involves the trunk and extremities. Over the past 4 days, he has had a mild sore throat, red, itchy eyes, and headache. He was born at term and has been healthy except for recurrent episodes of tonsillitis and occasional asthma attacks. Two weeks ago, he was treated for tonsillitis that resolved with penicillin therapy. He emigrated with his family from Japan 3 weeks ago. His immunization status is unknown. He appears well. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. There is a nonconfluent, pink maculopapular rash over the torso and extremities. His palms and soles show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measles typically manifest in two stages. The prodromal stage is characterized by a classic triad of coryza, cough, and conjunctivitis in combination with Koplik spots. It is followed by an exanthem stage in which patients usually develop a high fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, and a maculopapular, blanching, partially confluent exanthem that spreads from the face to the entire body. This patient's low-grade fever, postauricular lymphadenopathy, good general condition, and nonconfluent rash are not characteristic of measles.
Image Description:

Multiple maculopapular blanching and partially confluent patches are disseminated over the head, neck, and back of this young patient.

These findings are consistent with a desquamating rash, which can occur after fading of the first erythematous exanthema, caused by an infection with the measles virus.

B) INCORRECT:

Exanthem subitum usually manifests in patients between 6 months and 2 years of age, with almost all children being seropositive by the age of three. The typical presentation begins with a febrile phase, with abrupt onset high fever, cervical and/or occipital lymphadenopathy, inflamed tympanic membranes, and papular enanthem on the uvula and soft palate (Nagayama spots). After 2–3 days, patients subsequently develop a sudden decrease in temperature and a patchy, rose-pink, confluent, blanching, maculopapular exanthem that begins on the trunk and can spread to the face and extremities. The rash usually fades within a few hours to 2 days and can therefore easily go unnoticed. The patient's age, history of a progressive rash for 2 days, and the finding of a nonconfluent exanthem make another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Photograph of a 9-month-old infant with recent high fever

A patchy, macular exanthem is visible on the trunk, neck, and behind the ears. Symptoms developed after the fever resolved.

These features are consistent with roseola infantum.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with mild nonspecific symptoms (sore throat, low-grade fever, conjunctivitis, headache) and post-auricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy, followed by a nonconfluent, pink maculopapular rash, all of which suggest Rubella infection. The exanthem typically begins on the head and spreads to the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. During the prodromal phase, a maculopapular enanthem on the soft palate (Forchheimer sign) may be present.

Rubella was officially eliminated in the US in 2004 by widespread vaccination. However, sporadic cases may occur in unimmunized individuals with a recent history of migration to the US or travel to a country with a higher prevalence of the disease. While rubella is usually self-limited and has a benign course, infection during pregnancy can lead to congenital rubella syndrome, with cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss, and heart defects in the neonate.

D) INCORRECT:

Allergic drug reactions often present as a type IV hypersensitivity with a red, blanching maculopapular rash beginning on the head, then spreading to the trunk and extremities. While almost any oral medication can result in an allergic reaction, common causes are allopurinol, phenytoin, penicillin, and sulfa antibiotics. The exanthem usually begins 5–14 days after the medication has been initiated and may involve the palms, soles, and mucous membranes. Although this patient was treated with penicillin two weeks ago, the presence of lymphadenopathy without pruritus makes another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Upper body of a man presenting with a severely pruritic rash after getting a henna tattoo on the right arm

An erythematous papulovesicular rash is visible over the chest and arms. The rash is most severe around the henna tattoo, which appears markedly erythematous.

This is the typical appearance of allergic contact dermatitis.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with scarlet fever, an initial phase with fever, tonsillopharyngitis, and gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea) is usually followed by a scarlet‑colored maculopapular, blanching exanthem with a sandpaper-like texture. The rash typically begins on the neck and subsequently spreads to the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. Characteristic findings of scarlet fever are Pastia's lines, perioral pallor, and a strawberry tongue. After resolution of the rash, the skin typically desquamates in flakes, exposing new and tender epidermis. The examination findings presented in the case above are not consistent with those of scarlet fever.
Image Description:

The typical scarlet-colored, fine, maculopapular exanthem of scarlet fever is seen on the right arm. Flushed cheeks and perioral pallor are also evident.

F) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome usually begins 1–3 weeks after initiation of a medication (e.g., aminopenicillins, sulfonamides, allopurinol) and manifests with a high fever, myalgia, and a sore throat followed by mucocutaneous lesions. Skin findings include erythematous macules with a targetoid appearance, bullae and/or vesicles, epidermal necrosis, and sloughing. Involvement of the mucosal membranes is very common and leads to stomatitis, conjunctivitis with photophobia, dysphagia, diarrhea, and various other symptoms. The patient's presentation is not consistent with Stevens-Johnson syndrome; a different diagnosis is more likely.
Image Description:

Back, buttocks, thighs, and legs of an 8-month-old infant 2 weeks after primary vaccination

Irregularly shaped, partially confluent, erythematous macules with bullae are visible.

Patient history suggests Stevens-Johnson syndrome triggered by vaccination.

G) INCORRECT:

Patients with erythema infectiosum typically present with mild flu-like symptoms followed by a rash. The exanthem usually begins in the face as a “slapped-cheek rash” with perioral sparing and subsequently spreads to the trunk and extremities. Adults in particular often present with additional symptoms of arthralgia and symmetrical polyarthritis. The examination findings, in this case, are not consistent with erythema infectiosum.
Image Description:

The cheeks are bright red (slapped-cheek rash) and a diffuse, red, confluent rash with macules and papules is visible over the body of this infant.

This is the characteristic cutaneous appearance of erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which is caused by infection with parvovirus B19.

H) INCORRECT:

Chickenpox can manifest with prodromes such as fever and malaise; however, a rash is typically the first sign of infection. The exanthem typically starts on the trunk and subsequently spreads to the entire body, including the scalp and in some cases affecting the oral and urogenital mucosa, as well as the palms and soles. It is characterized by the simultaneous occurrence of various stages of rash (e.g., papules, vesicles, crusts) and severe pruritus. This patient's maculopapular rash is not consistent with chickenpox.
Image Description:

Upper body of a young boy with exanthem showing the simultaneous occurrence of various stages of rash; mainly vesicles and pustules, no crusted erosions. This clinical finding is also referred to as "starry sky" and is typical of chickenpox.
questions.hint: Older patients with this condition often present with polyarthritis.

questions.text: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a generalized nonpruritic rash for 2 days. The rash began on her trunk and spread to her extremities. Five days ago, she was taken to the emergency department for fever of 40.5°C (104.9°F) and a 1-minute generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The mother says the fever resolved abruptly. The patient was born at term and has no history of serious illness. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Current medications include acetaminophen. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F) and pulse is 120/min. Examination shows a maculopapular rash that blanches on pressure. A photograph of the rash is shown. Posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease is an acute vasculitis that manifests with high fever and a rash on the trunk. However, the patient is lacking other typical findings of Kawasaki disease, such as erythema on the hands and feet, conjunctivitis, and mucositis.

B) INCORRECT:

Scarlet fever is caused by infection with group A beta-hemolytic streptococci and occurs in a small percentage of people with throat infections. Even though scarlet fever would also manifest with a blanching, maculopapular rash, the rash has a fine, sandpaper-like texture. More importantly, however, the appearance of a rash would have been preceded by symptoms of acute tonsillitis (sore throat, difficulty swallowing, enlarged cervical lymph nodes).

C) CORRECT:

Roseola infantum (i.e., exanthem subitum) is a disease caused by the human herpesvirus 6 that primarily affects infants and young children. The infection is characterized by high fever, which ends abruptly after three to seven days (“three-day fever”), followed by the sudden appearance of a truncal rash that may spread to the face and extremities. Cervical and/or occipital lymphadenopathy are often present. Febrile seizures are a possible complication of infection; however, most patients recover from these seizures without any adverse outcome. Treatment is symptomatic as the disease is self-limiting.

See “Common causes of infectious rash in children” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Measles also manifests with a blanching, maculopapular rash, and fever in the exanthem stage. However, the exanthem stage is preceded by a prodromal stage that lasts ∼ 4–7 days and is characterized by cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis, which was not present in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Fifth disease is an illness caused by parvovirus B19 that manifests with a mild cold-like prodrome that is followed by a maculopapular rash with a slapped-cheek appearance after approximately 7–10 days. Although this infant has a maculopapular rash, it does not resemble a slapped-cheek appearance. Additionally, she had a high fever rather than a mild fever that would be expected in the prodrome phase.

F) INCORRECT:

Rubella also manifests with a maculopapular rash and postauricular lymphadenopathy. However, rubella typically only causes a mild fever, and the exanthem's course is typically independent of the timing of the fever. Additionally, the rash begins on the face/head and spreads to the trunk. In older patients, rubella often also manifests with polyarthritis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a nonpruritic, blanching, maculopapular rash that developed immediately after the abrupt cessation of a high fever.

questions.text: A 27-year-old gravida 2, para 1 comes to the physician because she has had an itchy rash all over her body for the past 3 days. It started on her face and gradually progressed downwards. She reports painless swelling of her knee joints and denies trauma. She had flu-like symptoms 3–4 days prior to the appearance of the rash. She has received no prenatal care. She delivered her first child vaginally without complications. She takes an iron supplement; her immunization records are unavailable. Examination shows a pink maculopapular rash over her body sparing her palms and soles. Postauricular lymphadenopathy is present. Knee joints are mildly swollen and range of motion is normal. Examination shows a uterus consistent with a 24-week gestation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used in the treatment of chickenpox (varicella zoster), which may cause congenital varicella syndrome. Chickenpox manifests with an itchy rash and a flu-like prodrome. This patient has a maculopapular rash instead of a vesiculopustular rash at different stages at once, the latter being typical for chickenpox. Additionally, the rash in chickenpox starts on the trunk, not on the face.

B) INCORRECT:

Counseling about the potentially devastating effects on the fetus and the possibility of terminating the pregnancy is indicated if maternal rubella infection occurs during the first trimester. The risk of congenital rubella syndrome is extremely low (< 1%) if fetal rubella infection occurs after 16 weeks of gestation. Given the incubation period of rubella infection (2–3 weeks) and the fact that clinical features of maternal rubella infection occurred at 24 weeks of gestation, it is safe to assume that this patient could have, at worst, acquired the infection at 21 weeks of gestation. Termination of pregnancy is therefore not recommended in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The rubella vaccine (MMR vaccine) is a live vaccine and is, therefore, contraindicated during pregnancy. Furthermore, vaccination would not be helpful for this patient who already has the condition. The MMR vaccine should, however, be administered to all nonpregnant women of childbearing age who have an unknown vaccination history or are seronegative for rubella-specific IgG.

D) CORRECT:

Rubella infection in a pregnant woman can put the fetus at risk of developing congenital rubella syndrome, especially during the first trimester. After the 16th week of gestation, however, the risk of developing congenital defects is very low; reassurance and symptomatic therapy (e.g., acetaminophen) are usually recommended. If rubella infection occurred before 16 weeks of gestation, the patient should be counseled about the potentially devastating effects on the fetus and the possibility of terminating the pregnancy.

E) INCORRECT:

If a pregnant woman is exposed to a patient with rubella, passive immunization with intravenous immunoglobulins (IVIG) within 5 days of exposure can prevent maternal rubella infection. However, routine administration of IVIG is not recommended if rubella infection has already become symptomatic. In addition, while it may reduce maternal symptoms, IVIG does not prevent congenital rubella syndrome. As this patient has mild symptoms and is already in the 24th week of her pregnancy, this intervention is not indicated.
questions.hint: An itchy maculopapular rash that started on the face and spread to the rest of the body but spares the palms and soles, in combination with postauricular lymphadenopathy and polyarthritis, is highly suggestive of rubella.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with bronchial asthma is brought to the physician by his mother because of a generalized rash for 2 days. He has also had a fever and sore throat for 3 days. The rash involves his whole body and is not pruritic. His only medication is a fluticasone/salmeterol inhaler. He has not received any routine childhood vaccinations. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F) and pulse is 102/min. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and a flushed face except around his mouth. A diffuse, maculopapular, erythematous rash that blanches with pressure is seen over the trunk with a linear, petechial appearance in the axilla and groin. Oropharyngeal examination shows pharyngeal erythema with a red beefy tongue. His hemoglobin is 13.5 mg/dL, leukocyte count is 13,200/mm3 (75% segmented neutrophils, 22% lymphocytes), and platelet count is 220,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely sequela of this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery aneurysms can occur as a complication of Kawasaki disease, a condition that should certainly be considered in a child presenting with fever, rash, and a strawberry tongue. However, this patient does not have other characteristic features, such as erythema and edema of the hands and feet, bilateral conjunctivitis, and oropharyngeal mucositis with cracked lips. Moreover, Kawasaki disease is a clinical diagnosis and requires the presence of a fever lasting for at least 5 days. The perioral pallor and Pastia lines seen here make scarlet fever the more likely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic anemia is a very rare complication of fifth disease (parvovirus B19 infection). Patients with fifth disease usually present similarly to the patient in this case, with flu-like symptoms, an exanthem on trunk and extremities, and a “slapped-cheek” rash with perioral sparing. However, this patient's pharyngitis, strawberry tongue, and Pastia lines are not typical of fifth disease and instead suggest scarlet fever.

C) INCORRECT:

Infectious mononucleosis (IM) is associated with several neoplasias, including Hodgkin lymphoma, Burkitt lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and hairy leukoplakia. IM can present with many symptoms that are similar to the ones seen in this patient such as fever, pharyngitis, and, occasionally, a maculopapular rash (usually following the administration of an aminopenicillin). However, other common features of IM such as splenomegaly, cervical lymphadenopathy, and exudative tonsillitis are absent in this patient. Also, laboratory evaluation in IM usually shows marked lymphocytosis. Perioral pallor and an erythematous tongue suggest another diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Postinfectious glomerulonephritis (or poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, PSGN) is a complication of group A streptococcal infections, such as tonsillopharyngitis, scarlet fever, and, less commonly, skin infections. This inflammatory sequela typically occurs approx. 1–6 weeks following an acute infection and is caused by immune complex deposition within the glomerular basement membrane, which leads to complement activation and subsequent destruction of the glomeruli. PSGN manifests with nephritic syndrome, which in most cases is self-limited and requires only supportive treatment.

Antibiotic treatment for group A streptococcal infection (e.g., with penicillin V) can decrease the risk of acute rheumatic fever but does not appear to lower the risk of PSGN.

E) INCORRECT:

Encephalitis is a dangerous late complication of measles or chickenpox. Because this patient has not received the recommended childhood vaccinations, this patient is at increased risk of developing several diseases, including measles and chickenpox. However, the rash typical of measles is usually preceded by coryza, cough and conjunctivitis (the “3 Cs”) and an enanthem of the buccal mucosa (Koplik spots), all of which are absent in this patient. Chickenpox, moreover, is notable for severely pruritic rash with macules that rapidly develop into papules and vesicles. Sore throat, perioral pallor, Pastia lines, and a strawberry tongue suggest scarlet fever.
questions.hint: Sore throat and fever followed by a diffuse, maculopapular, blanching rash with perioral pallor and a strawberry tongue indicate scarlet fever. The rash of scarlet fever is typically more marked in skin creases (e.g., axilla, groin) and has a linear, petechial appearance known as Pastia lines.

questions.text: A previously healthy 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of progressive rash. The rash started on his face, now involves the entire body, and is not itchy. For the past week, he has had a cough and a runny nose. He is visiting from the Philippines with his family. He is in first grade and spends his afternoons at an after-school child care program. Immunization records are not available. His temperature is 39.5°C (103°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 105/66 mm Hg. Examination shows generalized lymphadenopathy. There is an erythematous maculopapular, blanching, and partially confluent exanthem on his entire body. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rapid plasma reagin is used to diagnose syphilis. A diffuse, nonpruritic, erythematous, maculopapular exanthem, low-grade fever, and generalized lymphadenopathy occur in secondary syphilis but high-grade fever, cough, and coryza are not consistent with this condition. In addition, there are no risk factors for a pediatric syphilis infection (e.g., sexual abuse).

B) INCORRECT:

In the past, Tzanck smear of skin lesions had a role in the diagnosis of chickenpox (varicella) which manifests with constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise), followed by a widespread rash starting on the trunk, spreading to the face, scalp, and extremities. Unlike this patient's nonpruritic erythematous maculopapular rash, chickenpox causes a pruritic, polymorphic rash consisting of macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions.

C) CORRECT:

This patient initially had a prodrome of cough and coryza and subsequently developed generalized lymphadenopathy, high-grade fever, and an erythematous, maculopapular, blanching, partially confluent, and centrifugally spreading exanthem, all of which are highly suggestive of measles (see “Overview of infectious rashes in childhood” table). Serologic detection of measles-specific IgM antibodies and/or RT-PCR are the preferred tests to confirm acute measles infection. These antibodies may be negative during the prodromal phase and usually appear at the onset of the exanthem.

D) INCORRECT:

Rapid antigen detection testing (rapid strep test) is performed to detect group A β‑hemolytic streptococcus, which is the causative organism of scarlet fever. The exanthem seen in scarlet fever is a fine, papular rash that has a sandpaper‑like texture and is most pronounced in the intertriginous areas. In addition, scarlet fever usually manifests with tonsillopharyngitis but not cough, coryza, or conjunctivitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Serologic detection of rubella-specific IgM antibodies is performed to confirm the diagnosis of rubella, which can manifest with a mild, prodromal, flulike illness (more commonly in adolescents and adults than young children) and lymphadenopathy followed by a centrifugally spreading maculopapular exanthem. However, in rubella, the lymphadenopathy is typically localized (to the postauricular and suboccipital regions) rather than generalized, the rash is usually nonconfluent, and high-grade fever is not expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Anti-VCA IgM antibodies specific for EBV confirm the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis (IM), which can cause constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever) and lymphadenopathy (typically cervical but occasionally generalized). However, IM does not usually manifest with a rash (unless the patient received a beta-lactam antibiotic), cough, or coryza. Instead, features such as tonsillopharyngitis and splenomegaly would be expected.
questions.hint: This patient most likely did not receive the recommended childhood vaccinations and was infected with a paramyxovirus, which is associated with a high rate of complications including, e.g., bacterial superinfections.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of a 3-day history of generalized rash. The rash is not pruritic. He has no cough. He has had a fever and a sore throat for 4 days. He was born at term and has been healthy except for an episode of tonsillitis 6 months ago treated with erythromycin. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F). Examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. The tongue is bright red. There is tonsillar erythema with exudates. A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The monospot test can be used to support the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis (IM). This patient has fever, tonsillitis, and cervical lymphadenopathy which can also be seen in IM. Patients with IM who are treated with amoxicillin may present with a maculopapular rash. However, IM typically affects adolescents and frequently manifests with additional symptoms, e.g., splenomegaly and abdominal pain, making IM unlikely in this patient.

In addition, the monospot test is not used as a confirmatory test in IM because it carries a high risk of false positive and false negative results.

B) INCORRECT:

C-reactive protein may be elevated in scarlet fever. However, it is a nonspecific marker of inflammation and has no diagnostic value for scarlet fever.

C) INCORRECT:

Detection of elevated antistreptolysin O and anti‑deoxyribonuclease B titers can be used to diagnose streptococcal infection retrospectively, but they are of little use in determining the initial diagnosis or the appropriate treatment. These titers are more helpful when investigating potential complications such as rheumatic fever and post‑streptococcal glomerulonephritis after the initial infection has already subsided.

D) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography may be performed to evaluate for coronary artery aneurysm, a complication of Kawasaki disease. Although Kawasaki disease should always be considered in a young child presenting with fever and a rash, this patient does not have other characteristic features, such as erythema and edema of the hands and feet, bilateral conjunctivitis, and oropharyngeal mucositis with cracked lips. The erythematous maculopapular rash, perioral pallor, and exudative tonsillitis seen in this patient make scarlet fever the more likely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Detection of IgM antibodies may be performed to diagnose many viral illnesses (e.g., measles-specific IgM antibodies). This patient presents with fever, lymphadenopathy, and generalized rash, which are also features of measles. However, measles infection is typically characterized by a prodromal stage (coryza, cough, conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots) followed by erythematous maculopapular, blanching, and partially confluent exanthem. Moreover, IgM antibodies are not typically measured in the work-up of suspected scarlet fever, which requires another diagnostic test.

F) CORRECT:

Scarlet fever is caused by group A streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes or GAS), which produce erythrogenic scarlet fever exotoxins. A rapid streptococcal antigen test provides immediate detection of GAS and can be performed with a throat swab at the point of care (e.g., in the office or emergency department). If the initial result is positive, antibiotic treatment with oral penicillin V should be initiated. If negative, a follow-up test with a throat culture, which is the gold standard for confirmation of GAS infection, is needed.
questions.hint: This patient presents with exudative tonsillitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, a strawberry tongue, flushed cheeks with perioral pallor, and an erythematous maculopapular rash that appeared one day after the onset of fever. These findings are characteristic of scarlet fever.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a generalized rash for 3 days. Over the past 5 days, he has also had a high fever and a sore throat. He returned from a summer camp a week ago. His 16-year-old sister was treated for infectious mononucleosis 2 weeks ago. His immunizations are up-to-date. Three years ago, he required intubation after an allergic reaction to dicloxacillin. The patient appears ill. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Examination shows circumferential oral pallor. Cervical lymphadenopathy is present. There is tonsillar erythema and exudate. A confluent, blanching, punctate erythematous rash with a rough texture is spread over his trunk and extremities. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.3 g/dL, leukocyte count is 12,000/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 43 mm/h. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus infections, chickenpox, and herpes zoster (shingles). A herpetiform rash is usually characterized by vesicles and crusted lesions. This patient's confluent, blanching, punctate erythematous rash is characteristic of scarlet fever.

B) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is the treatment of choice for tick-borne diseases such as Lyme disease and Rocky mountain spotted fever (RMSF) and has recently been approved for short-term use in children < 8 years of age. This patient presents with fever, malaise, and a rash after returning from summer camp, which is consistent with both conditions. However, early Lyme disease manifests with erythema chronicum migrans rather than a generalized rash. While RMSF manifests with a blanching maculopapular rash, the rash typically begins on the wrists and ankles, spreads to the trunk, palms, and soles, and becomes petechial and/or hemorrhagic. Moreover, RMSF is associated with further symptoms such as swelling of the ankles and/or wrists as well as gastrointestinal and neurological symptoms. This patient's exudative tonsillitis and perioral pallor suggest scarlet fever, for which doxycycline is not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

For many of the viral childhood exanthems (e.g., erythema infectiosum, roseola infantum, infectious mononucleosis (IM)), symptomatic treatment is sufficient. Patients with infections caused by group A streptococci (GAS), such as scarlet fever or tonsillopharyngitis, however, should always receive antibiotic treatment.

Since the patient's sister was recently treated for IM, it should certainly be considered as a differential diagnosis. Patients with IM can present with symptoms similar to those of scarlet fever, such as tonsillopharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, and sometimes a rash. Differentiation between the two diseases is important, as the use of ampicillin (used for GAS infection) in patients with IM can lead to the development of a disseminated rash. This patient's perioral pallor and rash indicate scarlet fever.

D) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin is often given as the treatment of choice for scarlet fever in children. However, this patient experienced a life-threatening adverse reaction following the administration of a penicillin antibiotic, indicating a severe penicillin allergy. Administration of amoxicillin is therefore contraindicated.

E) CORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment is indicated in all patients with group A streptococcal infection (e.g., tonsillopharyngitis, scarlet fever) to shorten the period of infectivity and prevent acute complications (e.g., peritonsillar abscess) and inflammatory sequela (e.g., acute rheumatic fever). As this patient has a history of severe penicillin allergy, the first-line treatment options (penicillin V or amoxicillin) are contraindicated and a macrolide such as azithromycin should be used instead. Patients with a history of mild allergic reaction to penicillin (e.g., rash) can be treated with an oral cephalosporin.

Ideally, before treatment is initiated, group A streptococcal infection should be confirmed with rapid strep test and/or throat culture in order to avoid the unnecessary use of antibiotics.

F) INCORRECT:

Narrow-spectrum cephalosporins like cephalexin can be used in the treatment of scarlet fever in patients with a history of mild reactions to penicillin (e.g., maculopapular rash). However, cephalosporins should generally be avoided in patients with known severe penicillin allergy, such as this boy who has previously required intubation after administration of a penicillin, because cross-reactivity can lead to allergic reactions and anaphylaxis.

G) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulins are not indicated for infections such as scarlet fever, but are used to treat a variety of conditions, including Kawasaki disease. Patients with Kawasaki disease present in early childhood with fever, erythema, and edema of hands and feet, a polymorphous rash, conjunctivitis, erythema, and swelling of the tongue (strawberry tongue), and cervical lymphadenopathy. This patient's perioral pallor, tonsillopharyngitis and spared palms/soles make Kawasaki disease unlikely.
questions.hint: Sore throat and high fever followed by a rough, blanching erythematous rash with perioral pallor indicate scarlet fever. First-line treatment cannot be administered due to the patient's history of an anaphylactic reaction to a penicillin antibiotic.

questions.text: A previously healthy 11-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of fever, cough, and a runny nose. During this period, he has also had pink, itchy eyes. The patient emigrated from Syria 2 weeks ago. His parents died 6 months ago. He has not yet received any routine childhood vaccinations. He lives at a foster home with ten other refugees; two have similar symptoms. He appears anxious and is sweating. His temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctivitis of both eyes. There are multiple, 2-mm-sized, blue-white papules with an erythematous rim on the buccal mucosa and the soft palate. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aplastic crisis may occur as a complication in patients with erythema infectiosum, which is characterized by a prodrome of mild flu-like symptoms followed by diffuse redness of the face with perioral sparing (“slapped‑cheek rash”) without any enanthem. This patient's clinical features are consistent with a measles infection, which does not cause aplastic anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery aneurysm is a potential complication of Kawasaki disease (KD), which can also cause high fever and conjunctivitis. However, other cardinal features of KD include a polymorphous rash, mucositis (e.g., “strawberry tongue”, cracked lips), cervical lymphadenopathy, as well as erythema and edema of the distal extremities. Also, KD primarily occurs in children < 5 years of Asian and Pacific-Islander descent, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this 11-year-old boy from Syria.

C) INCORRECT:

Glomerulonephritis can develop after a streptococcal infection such as scarlet fever. While the prodrome of scarlet fever also manifests with fever, other expected features include tonsillopharyngitis, a white-coated or strawberry-red tongue, cervical lymphadenopathy, and/or gastrointestinal symptoms. This patient presents with symptoms suggestive of measles, which is not associated with glomerulonephritis.

D) CORRECT:

Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare complication of measles infection. SSPE usually develops at least 7 years after the initial infection with measles and is characterized by dementia, myoclonus, and epilepsy, leading to coma and death. Diagnosis is established based on electroencephalography and cerebral spinal fluid analysis. Although there is no treatment available for SSPE, both measles infection, and SSPE are typically prevented by a live, attenuated virus in combination with the mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine, which is given during childhood.

In addition to SSPE, measles can also cause acute complications like bacterial superinfection (otitis media, pneumonia), (viral) giant-cell pneumonia, gastroenteritis, or acute encephalitis that may lead to acute disseminated encephalomyelitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) is associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. Acute EBV infection (infectious mononucleosis) is characterized by fever, fatigue, tonsillopharyngitis, bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. This patient presents with measles, which is not associated with NHL.
Image Description:

Enlarged, inflamed tonsil (green overlay) with gray-white deposits (white outline) in a patient with infectious mononucleosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) may occur as a complication of rubella, which typically manifests with a prodrome of fever, conjunctivitis, a petechial enanthem of the soft palate (Forchheimer sign), and postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. Rarely, ITP occurs following measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccination but ITP is not a complication of measles infection.
questions.hint: This unvaccinated patient has a 3-day history of coryza, cough, conjunctivitis (the “3 Cs”), fever, and multiple blue-white lesions on an erythematous background (Koplik spots), all of which suggest an active measles infection in the prodromal (catarrhal) stage.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of a progressive rash that started 2 days ago. The rash began on the face and progressed to the trunk and extremities. Over the past week, he has had a runny nose, a cough, and red, crusty eyes. He immigrated with his family from Turkey 3 months ago. His father and his older brother have Behçet disease. Immunization records are unavailable. The patient appears irritable and cries during the examination. His temperature is 40.0°C (104°F). Examination shows generalized lymphadenopathy and dry mucous membranes. Skin turgor is decreased. There is a blanching, partially confluent erythematous maculopapular exanthem. Examination of the oral cavity shows two 5-mm aphthous ulcers at the base of the tongue. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 6000/mm3, and platelet count is 215,000/mm3. Serology confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Attenuated live vaccine against measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR)

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

IVIG can be used as postexposure prophylaxis (within 6 days of exposure) for measles in infants younger than 12 months of age, pregnant women without evidence of measles immunity, and immunocompromised patients. As the disease is already in the exanthem stage, it is now too late for postexposure prophylaxis. Another possible indication for IVIG would be Kawasaki disease, but the child lacks the typical red tongue and rash with palmar and plantar desquamation.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral acyclovir is used to treat patients with chickenpox who are at high risk for complications (e.g., immunocompromised individuals). However, chickenpox manifests as an itchy rash with blisters, crusts, and scabs and does not cause purely maculopapular exanthem. This patient has measles for which oral acyclovir is not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Prednisone can be used to treat Behcet disease, which is present in the child's father and sibling. Although this child has aphthous ulcers, other typical manifestations of Behcet disease, such as ocular involvement and abdominal discomfort are absent. Additionally, Behcet disease is not known to cause a widespread rash.

D) INCORRECT:

The MMR vaccine has no benefit during the exanthem phase of measles and is contraindicated if the child has a high fever. MMR can be administered within 72 hours of exposure to measles in immunocompetent patients (postexposure prophylaxis) or in nonresponders to vaccination (as determined by serologic testing).

E) CORRECT:

Vitamin A supplementation can help prevent complications of measles such as otitis media, viral pneumonia, encephalitis, or corneal ulceration. Vitamin A supplementation does not cure measles, but decreases both morbidity and mortality, especially in malnourished children. The CDC recommends administration to children with severe measles, while the WHO and the American Academy of Pediatrics Red Book recommend administration to all children with measles.

Aphthous ulcers can occur with any febrile illness and should not be confused with the tiny white lesions on the buccal mucosa (Koplik spots) that are pathognomonic for measles. Koplik spots typically fade 1–2 days after the onset of the rash.

F) INCORRECT:

Although measles is commonly a self-limiting disease, it can lead to a variety of complications like otitis media, viral pneumonia, or encephalitis. Reassurance and follow-up would not be adequate.

G) INCORRECT:

Oral penicillin V is used to treat various infections, such as scarlet fever. Although scarlet fever also presents with a blanching, maculopapular rash, the rash would have a sandpaper-like texture and be most prominent in flexural areas. Additionally, scarlet fever is characterized by a history of pharyngitis and a typical strawberry tongue on examination.
questions.hint: Coryza, cough, and conjunctivitis followed by a maculopapular, blanching, partially confluent, centrifugally spreading exanthem are characteristic of measles, which often leads to dehydration, as in this child.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of increasing pain and swelling of her hands and wrists. She has been unable to continue her daily activities like writing or driving. She has had a nonpruritic generalized rash for 4 days. She had a fever and a runny nose one week ago which resolved with over-the-counter medication. She is sexually active with a male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. She works as an attendant at an amusement park. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. Examination shows swelling and tenderness of the wrists as well as the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. Range of motion of the wrists is limited. A lacy macular rash is noted over the trunk and extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate and antinuclear antibody and anti-dsDNA serology, show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 infection, also known as erythema infectiosum or fifth disease, is a common childhood disease that can also affect adults. The disease typically manifests with mild febrile illness, occasionally followed by a maculopapular rash beginning on the perioral areas of the face several days later and spreading to the extremities from there. As the rash clears, it adopts a lacy and reticular pattern. Parvovirus B19 infection in adults may also manifest with symptoms of symmetric polyarthritis in the fingers, hands, knees, and ankles while the rash can be absent. The disease is usually self-limited and treatment is supportive, involving analgesics and NSAIDs.

B) INCORRECT:

Common findings in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) include fever and joint pain as seen in this young female patient. However, dermatologic findings of SLE often include a malar rash, photosensitivity, or discoid lupus rather than a self-limited reticular rash on the extremities. In addition, this patient also has normal hemoglobin, normal ESR, negative antinuclear antibodies, negative anti-dsDNA, and normal renal function, which would be unlikely in SLE.

C) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis manifests with the classic triad of acute onset of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis in roughly a third of cases. Although reactive arthritis can also be associated with fever and a runny nose, joint involvement usually includes asymmetrical migratory polyarthritis in the lower extremities, sacroiliitis, or enthesopathy. Furthermore, the patient does not have conjunctivitis, uveitis, oral lesions, diarrhea, or any urogenital tract symptoms that also present with reactive arthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Around 2% of patients with Neisseria gonorrhoeae develop disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI). Although DGI may manifest with fever and polyarthralgias in the hands, this patient is missing other common symptoms such as dermatitis and tenosynovitis. Furthermore, arthritis caused by DGI is migratory and asymmetric, while this patient has symmetric polyarthritis in her hands and wrists.
Image Description:

A pustule with surrounding erythema is located on the left palm in the area of the 5th metacarpal bone.

E) INCORRECT:

Psoriatic arthritis can manifest with or without skin or nail findings and can also cause either symmetrical polyarthritis as in this patient or asymmetrical oligoarticular arthritis. However, the condition commonly involves the spine, the sacroiliac joint, and the distal interphalangeal joints, none of which are affected in this patient. Furthermore, psoriatic arthritis does not cause a reticular rash on the extremities, and lab values typically show an elevated ESR as psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory condition.

F) INCORRECT:

Although this patient had symptoms that could be attributable to rheumatoid arthritis (RA), such as fever and symmetric polyarthralgia in the hands and wrists, this diagnosis is less likely because of her rash, normal ESR, and acute onset. If her arthritis symptoms do not resolve within a few weeks, however, she should undergo more specific testing for RA.
questions.hint: This young woman with a recent history of flu-like symptoms, a nonpruritic generalized rash, and acute bilateral upper extremity arthralgias likely contracted a self-limited disease given her exposure to young children.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of fever and a non-itchy rash. The mother reports that he has had difficulty eating since yesterday. He has not had a cough, nausea, or vomiting. He was born at term and has been healthy. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears irritable. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Examination shows tender, erythematous macules and papules over the knees, buttocks, palms, and soles. There are multiple 2-mm ulcers on the buccal mucosa. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely infectious agent?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Human herpesvirus 6 causes roseola infantum, which manifests with fever, a nonpruritic maculopapular exanthem that can extend to the extremities, and occasionally an enanthem. However, the exanthem is nontender, occurs only after the fever subsides (fever due to roseola lasts for 3–7 days), predominantly affects the trunk, and does not affect the palms and soles. The enanthem of roseola infantum (Nagayama spots) is characterized by erythematous papules rather than ulcers.

B) INCORRECT:

Rubella manifests with fever and a maculopapular exanthem that typically arises on the face and then spreads to the trunk and extremities. In some cases, an enanthem may be present (Forchheimer sign) but these appear as petechiae rather than ulcers. Moreover, the exanthem of rubella is nontender, does not affect the palms and soles, and is preceded by a prodromal phase with postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. This patient's up-to-date immunization status also makes rubella very unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus 1 causes herpetic gingivostomatitis, which can also manifest with fever and ulcerative enanthem. However, the condition is restricted to the oral cavity rather than presenting with eruption on other parts of the body.
Image Description:

Multiple red erosions can be seen on the lips. Intact vesicles with surrounding erythema are visible on the tongue.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpetic gingivostomatitis.

D) CORRECT:

Coxsackie A virus causes HFMD, which affects primarily infants and young children and is characterized by fever, an enanthem of the oral cavity, and a nonpruritic exanthem that mainly involves the palms and soles but can occasionally spread to the limbs and buttocks. A prodromal phase is usually absent. The exanthem is often initially maculopapular and progresses to vesicular lesions that can ulcerate. The various morphologies of the exanthem may be present simultaneously and the exanthem can occasionally be tender (with certain Coxsackie A serotypes). The enanthem is typically painful (causing odynophagia or refusal to eat), appears as erythematous macules, vesicles, or ulcers, and most commonly involves the tongue or buccal mucosa. The disease is most often self-limiting and supportive treatment (e.g., pain relief) is usually sufficient. Rarely, patients can develop neurological complications (e.g., meningitis).

See “Overview of infectious rashes in childhood” table.
Image Description:

12-month-old infant

Typical white-gray blisters with a diameter of approx. 3–5 mm surrounded by an erythematous halo are seen on the fingers (top images). Another common finding, as seen here, is a disseminated macular and papular rash on the upper and lower legs (bottom left). In addition, there is a partially crusted papulovesicular rash in the perioral region (bottom right). However, the eponymous involvement of the mouth refers to the typically painful aphthous enanthem of the oral mucosa, which is not shown here.

E) INCORRECT:

Varicella-zoster virus causes chickenpox, which is characterized by a rash that typically starts on the trunk and then spreads to the entire body, and in some cases, the oral mucosa as well as the palms and soles. The localization of this patient's rash is different from the one seen in chickenpox. Furthermore, chickenpox is characterized by a nontender but itchy rash with various stages (i.e., papules, vesicles, crusts) that appear simultaneously. Chickenpox is also unlikely because of the patient's up-to-date immunization status.

F) INCORRECT:

Measles manifests with fever, a maculopapular exanthem, and an enanthem but it also causes cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis (the 3 C's!), which this patient does not have. Moreover, the exanthem of measles rarely involves the palms and soles and the enanthem of measles (Koplik spots) is characterized by white or bluish-white spots rather than ulcers. This patient's up-to-date immunization status also makes measles very unlikely.

G) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 causes fifth disease, which manifests with a flu-like prodrome that is followed by a maculopapular exanthem 7–10 days later that classically causes a slapped-cheek appearance and sometimes spreads to the trunk and limbs. The exanthem of fifth disease is nontender and does not involve the palms and soles. Moreover, fifth disease does not manifest with an enanthem.

H) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus causes impetigo. The disease affects primarily the face and extremities and typically presents with honey-colored vesicles, pustules, or crusted lesions on an erythematous background. The lesions are rarely painful and patients are typically afebrile. Impetigo can cause perioral lesions but does not typically cause an enanthem.
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.
questions.hint: This patient has manifestations suggestive of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD).

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a generalized rash for 3 days. During this period, he has had severe itching and was not able to sleep well. He has also had fever, headache, and some muscle pain. Five days ago, he had a runny nose which subsided with over-the-counter medications. He returned from a camping trip 1 week ago. He attends a daycare center. The patient is at the 55th percentile for height and at the 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 96/60 mm Hg. Examination of the skin shows several macules, papules, and crusted lesions over his face, trunk, and extremities. There are a few fluid-filled vesicles over his abdomen and back. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient had coryza and fever, both of which are often seen in patients with measles. However, measles typically manifests with a nonpruritic, erythematous, maculopapular, blanching, partially confluent exanthem, which is markedly different from this patient's lesions (macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions). Also, this boy does not have any of the symptoms that are typically concomitantly present in measles, such as cough, conjunctivitis, or generalized lymphadenopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient was on a recent hiking trip, putting him at risk for skin exposure to urushiol-containing plants, which can result in urushiol-induced contact dermatitis. Similar to this boy's skin findings, the rash seen in urushiol-induced dermatitis is also highly pruritic and vesicular. However, it is usually localized to where the plant came into contact with the skin (e.g., the legs, arms, hands). Also, a contact dermatitis rash develops 12–48 hours after antigen exposure; this patient returned from his camping trip 4 days before the onset of his symptoms.
Image Description:

An erythematous rash with numerous small vesicles in a linear pattern can be seen on the left forearm.

This rash is typical of mild allergic contact dermatitis caused by urushiol-containing plants (e.g., poison oak). In more severe cases, bullae and pronounced edema may be present.

C) INCORRECT:

The rash seen in scarlet fever is typically fine, erythematous, and maculopapular (often described as sandpaper-like), unlike in this patient who presents with macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions. Also, apart from fever, he does not have any symptoms that are characteristically seen in scarlet fever (e.g., throat pain, cervical lymphadenopathy).

D) INCORRECT:

Roseola infantum primarily affects children between 2 months and 2 years of age and typically manifests with a very high fever that ends abruptly before the sudden appearance of a rash. In contrast, this patient's fever and exanthema are present at the same time. Also, his rash is both maculopapular and papulovesicular, different from the rose-pink maculopapular, patchy, blanching exanthem typically seen in roseola infantum. In addition, roseola infantum almost always presents with cervical and/or occipital lymphadenopathy.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's constitutional symptoms (fever, headache, and myalgia) along with a highly pruritic, generalized rash with multiple lesions in different stages (macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions) are characteristic of chickenpox. Chickenpox is usually a clinical diagnosis made on the basis of the characteristic rash, although further tests may be necessary in atypical or complicated cases (e.g., older or immunosuppressed patients, pregnant women). A PCR from skin lesions to evaluate for VZV DNA is the preferred test for confirmation.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with erythema infectiosum also present with fever and a pruritic rash. However, erythema infectiosum rash is usually only mildly pruritic and initially pronounced on the cheeks (i.e., slapped‑cheek rash) before spreading to the extremities and trunk where it adopts a lace-like and reticular appearance. This patient's highly pruritic rash with fluid-filled vesicles and crusted lesions is inconsistent with erythema infectiosum.

G) INCORRECT:

The patient was on a hiking trip which puts him at risk for tick bites and contracting tick-borne diseases such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF). Although fever, headache, and myalgia are commonly seen in patients with RMSF, these symptoms usually occur several days prior to the onset of a rash. Also, the rash seen in RMSF is not associated with crusts and vesicles and typically follows a particular pattern that begins on the wrists and ankles, then spreads to the trunk, palms, and soles.
Image Description:

Multiple, partly confluent, macules are visible on this patient's forearm.

This rash is suggestive of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), a tick-borne disease caused by Rickettsia rickettsii bacteria. The distal extremities are usually affected first; the rash then spreads toward the proximal extremities and the trunk (the face, however, is usually spared).

H) INCORRECT:

While this patient's fever, headache, myalgia, coryza, and development of a rash could be signs of rubella, the rash seen in rubella is usually only mildly pruritic, maculopapular, and not associated with any vesicles or crusted lesions. Also, affected children commonly have concomitant postauricular and/or suboccipital lymphadenopathy.
questions.hint: The causative pathogen in this patient's case can remain dormant in dorsal root ganglia and get reactivated after several years, leading to a dermatomal rash with painful blistering.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because of a 3-day history of sore throat, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and high fever. She has been taking acetaminophen for the fever. Physical examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy, pharyngeal erythema, and a bright red tongue. Examination of the skin shows a generalized erythematous rash with a rough surface that spares the area around the mouth. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's rash?

choices.text: Bacterial invasion of the deep dermis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Type IV hypersensitivity is a T cell-mediated reaction that manifests with a erythematous maculopapular skin rash, as in this patient. However, it is unlikely to be the cause of this patient's symptoms, as drug eruptions are intensely pruritic and do not present with circumoral pallor or a red tongue. Type IV hypersensitivity reactions occur after use of topical antibiotics such as neomycin, contact with urushiol (e.g. in poison ivy), or contact with latex (i.e., latex gloves).
Image Description:

Ventral upper body of a patient presenting with a pruritic rash following the administration of amoxicillin

A diffuse rash composed of several fine erythematous papules is visible. This rash, known as a morbilliform rash because it resembles the rash seen in measles, is typical of a drug reaction.

B) INCORRECT:

Rheumatic fever is a complication of group A streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis. It is caused by a type II hypersensitivity reaction from antibodies created against streptoccocal M protein, which cross-react with proteins of the heart, joints, and nerves through molecular mimicry. While this patient has pharyngitis, skin rash, and fever, these symptoms are unlikely to be due to rheumatic fever since there is no evidence of joint and cardiac involvement, Sydenham chorea, subcutaneous nodules, or skin nodules (JONES criteria). Rheumatic fever manifests with an evanescent rash with well delineated ring-shaped margins (erythema marginatum).

C) INCORRECT:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is caused by subepithelial immune complex deposition within the glomerular basement membrane, resulting in complement activation, destruction of the glomeruli, and nephritic syndrome. It usually occurs 1–6 weeks after an acute infection of the skin (impetigo) or the pharynx (pharyngitis) and manifests with hematuria, hypertension, flank pain, and edema. Since this patient only has a 3-day history of sore throat and no evidence of nephritic syndrome, PSGN is very unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has typical features of scarlet fever due to Streptococcus pyogenes (group A streptococcus, GAS), a gram-positive bacteria whose release of erythrogenic toxin A, B, or C, results in excessive release of inflammatory mediators. The rash in scarlet fever blanches with pressure and is most pronounced in flexural areas such as axillae, popliteal fossae, and the inguinal region. Other toxigenic effects of GAS infection include streptococcal toxic shock syndrome, erysipelas, and necrotizing fasciitis.

All cases of scarlet fever should be treated with antibiotics such as penicillin V or, in patients allergic to penicillin, macrolides.

E) INCORRECT:

Bacterial invasion of the deep dermis manifests as cellulitis, a skin infection caused by group A streptococci. Skin infections usually result from minor skin injuries (e.g., cuts, blisters, scratches), which allow bacteria to spread through superficial lymphatic vessels, resulting in skin rash and fever. However, cellulitis is unlikely to be the cause of this patient's symptoms, since the rash in cellulitis is limited to the site of infection rather than generalized.

F) INCORRECT:

Paramyxovirus-induced cell damage is seen in measles (rubeola), which presents with a generalized, erythematous, and maculopapular skin rash, as seen in this patient. However, measles is characterized by generalized lymphadenopathy and is preceded by a prodrome of coryza, cough, conjunctivitis (the “3 Cs”), and Koplik spots.
questions.hint: This girl presents with typical clinical findings of scarlet fever including high fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, a fine sandpaper-like rash with circumoral pallor, tonsillopharyngitis, and strawberry tongue.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a generalized, non-itchy rash for 2 days. He has also had a fever and sore throat for 4 days. He has not received any routine childhood vaccinations. Examination shows a flushed face except around his mouth. A diffuse, papular, erythematous rash that blanches with pressure is seen over the trunk. Pharyngeal erythema and a red beefy tongue are noted. His leukocyte count is 11,200/mm3 (75% segmented neutrophils, 22% lymphocytes). Without treatment, this patient's current condition puts him at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic anemia is a very rare complication of fifth disease (parvovirus B19 infection). Patients with fifth disease usually present similarly to the patient in this case, with flu-like symptoms, an exanthem on trunk and extremities, and a “slapped-cheek” rash with perioral sparing. However, this patient's pharyngitis and a strawberry tongue are not typical of fifth disease and instead suggest scarlet fever.

While autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) can occur as a complication of the disease, a more common complication involving the red blood cells is transient aplastic crisis. It usually occurs in patients with an underlying hemolytic anemia (e.g., sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis, thalassemia), leading to severe anemia and, in some cases, the need for blood transfusions.

B) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery aneurysms can occur as a complication of Kawasaki disease (KD), which presents with fever, a polymorphous rash, conjunctivitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, and erythema or edema of the hands, feet, and tongue (strawberry tongue). KD is a clinical diagnosis and requires a fever for at least 5 days in combination with at least 4 of these symptoms. While it is certainly an important differential diagnosis in this case (erythematous tongue, rash, fever), the patient does not fulfill the other diagnostic criteria for KD.

C) INCORRECT:

Splenic rupture is a complication of splenomegaly seen in infectious mononucleosis (IM) and is usually triggered by contact sport or other blunt abdominal impact. IM can present with many symptoms that are similar to the ones seen in this patient such as fever, pharyngitis, and, occasionally, a maculopapular rash (usually following the administration of an aminopenicillin). However, other common features of IM, such as cervical lymphadenopathy, and exudative tonsillitis, are absent in this patient. Also, laboratory evaluation in IM usually shows marked lymphocytosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Encephalitis is a dangerous late complication of measles or chickenpox. Because this patient has not received the recommended childhood vaccinations, this patient is at increased risk of developing several diseases, including measles and chickenpox. However, the rash typical of measles is usually preceded by coryza, cough and conjunctivitis (the “3 Cs”) and an enanthem of the buccal mucosa (Koplik spots), all of which are absent in this patient. Chickenpox, moreover, is notable for severely pruritic rash with macules that rapidly develop into papules and vesicles.

Routine immunization with the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine and the varicella vaccine is recommended for all children at 12–15 months and between 4 and 6 years. Vaccination programs have greatly reduced the incidence of these diseases and their complications.

E) CORRECT:

Mitral valve regurgitation (MR) is a complication of untreated group A streptococcal (GAS) infections such as scarlet fever and tonsillopharyngitis. MR is the result of rheumatic heart disease, which can cause early mitral regurgitation or prolapse and later evolves into mitral stenosis.

Impetigo contagiosum is another GAS infection that is more often associated with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis and is less commonly associated with rheumatic heart disease.

F) INCORRECT:

Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. Although the presumed pathophysiology of minimal change disease is presumed to be the result of a dysregulated T-cell response, it is not yet fully understood. There is no known association between group A streptococcal infections such as scarlet fever and the development of minimal change disease.

Postinfectious glomerulonephritis (or poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, PSGN) can be a complication of infections with group A Streptococcus (S. pyogenes; GAS) such as scarlet fever, tonsillopharyngitis, or impetigo. PSGN is caused by immune complex deposition and subsequent destruction of the glomeruli. Patients typically present with symptoms of nephritic syndrome (e.g., hypertension, edema, hematuria).
questions.hint: Sore throat and fever followed by a diffuse macular rash, an erythematous tongue (strawberry tongue), and perioral pallor are indicative of scarlet fever.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after the sudden onset of a rash that started on the head and progressed to the trunk and extremities. Over the past week, he has had a runny nose, a cough, and red, crusty eyes. He recently immigrated with his family from Yemen and immunization records are unavailable. The patient appears malnourished. His temperature is 40.0°C (104°F). Examination shows generalized lymphadenopathy and a blanching, partially confluent maculopapular exanthema. Administration of which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Valacyclovir is used to treat VZV and HSV infections. Primary HSV infection in children typically presents as gingivostomatitis with bloody gingival ulcerations and mucosal blisters. Cervical lymphadenopathy, but not generalized lymphadenopathy, may be present. Furthermore, facial rash is not typical for HSV infection. VZV infection (chickenpox) presents with a widespread rash that starts on the trunk, and eventually spreads to the face, scalp, and extremities as opposed to the progression from face to trunk seen in this patient. In VZV infection, the various stages of the rash typically occur simultaneously. Valacyclovir is not effective against the rubeola virus that causes measles.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral penicillin V is used to treat various diseases, including scarlet fever, which also manifests with a blanching, maculopapular rash. However, in scarlet fever, the rash would have a sandpaper-like texture and be most prominent in flexural areas. In addition, scarlet fever is characterized by a history of pharyngitis (sore throat), flushed cheeks with perioral pallor, and a characteristic white-coated or strawberry-red tongue

C) CORRECT:

While there is no curative treatment for measles, the administration of vitamin A (retinol) can help prevent complications such as otitis media, viral pneumonia, encephalitis, and subacute sclerosing panencephalitis. Vitamin A enhances the barrier function and immunity of the ocular, respiratory, and gastrointestinal epithelium. Lower serum levels of vitamin A are associated with a more severe and prolonged course of the disease. The CDC recommends administration to children with severe measles, while the WHO and the American Academy of Pediatrics Red Book recommend administration to all children with measles.

The small white or bluish-white spot on the buccal mucosa (Koplik spots) that are pathognomonic for measles typically appear in the prodromal phase of the disease. Perhaps this patient had Koplik spots, but they typically fade as the rash appears.

D) INCORRECT:

While the MMR vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine, it has no benefit during the exanthem phase of measles and is, in fact, contraindicated if the child has a high fever, as in this case. MMR vaccine can be administered within 72 hours of exposure to measles in immunocompetent patients (postexposure prophylaxis) or in nonresponders to vaccination as determined by serologic testing.

E) INCORRECT:

IVIG can be used as postexposure prophylaxis (within 6 days of exposure) for measles in infants younger than 12 months of age, pregnant women without evidence of measles immunity, and people with severely compromised immune systems. As, in this patient, the disease is already in the exanthem stage, it is now too late for postexposure prophylaxis. Another possible indication for IVIG would be Kawasaki disease, but the child does not have the characteristic strawberry tongue and rash with palmar and plantar desquamation.
questions.hint: Coryza, cough, and conjunctivitis followed by maculopapular, blanching, partially confluent exanthema are characteristic of measles.

questions.text: A previously healthy 10-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of severe malaise, pink eyes, cough, and a runny nose for 3 days. She recently immigrated from Sudan and immunization records are unavailable. Her temperature is 40.1°C (104.1°F). Examination shows bilateral conjunctival injections. There are multiple bluish-white lesions on an erythematous buccal mucosa and soft palate. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery aneurysm is a potential complication of Kawasaki disease (KD), which can also cause high fever and conjunctivitis. However, other cardinal features of KD include a polymorphous rash, mucositis (e.g., “strawberry tongue”, cracked lips), cervical lymphadenopathy, as well as erythema and edema of the distal extremities, all of which are absent in this patient. Also, KD primarily occurs in children < 5 years of age who are of Asian and Pacific-Islander descent. It is an unlikely diagnosis in this 10-year-old girl from Sudan.

B) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura presents with a decreased platelet count and several nonblanching, red/purple spots on the skin. ITP may also occur as a complication of rubella. Although patients with rubella can also present with fever, conjunctivitis, and an enanthem of the soft palate (Forchheimer sign), they typically have postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. Furthermore, the Koplik spots described here are characteristic of measles.

C) CORRECT:

Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a rare and currently untreatable complication of measles infection that usually develops many years after the initial infection. Although the exact etiology of SSPE is not fully understood, it is thought to result from persistent replication of a defective variant of the measles virus within neurons and glial cells. Particles of this defective virus accumulate intracellularly and are detectable as inclusion bodies on brain tissue analysis. These particles cause inflammation of the parenchyma and ultimately lead to neuronal degeneration, gliosis, and demyelination. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows high levels of anti-measles antibodies.

Measles, with all of its other complications (including bacterial superinfection, giant-cell pneumonia, gastroenteritis, and acute encephalomyelitis), can easily be prevented by the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine.

D) INCORRECT:

Epstein-Barr virus, a known etiology of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (particularly in immunocompromised patients), causes infectious mononucleosis (IM). IM is characterized by splenomegaly, fever, fatigue, pharyngitis and/or tonsillitis, and bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. Although this patient presents with fever, she does not have any of the other typical symptoms of IM. Also, measles infection is not associated with non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
Image Description:

Enlarged, inflamed tonsil (green overlay) with gray-white deposits (white outline) in a patient with infectious mononucleosis.

E) INCORRECT:

A transient arrest of erythropoiesis and resulting drop in hemoglobin are characteristic of aplastic crisis, which may occur as a complication of erythema infectiosum. Erythema infectiosum is characterized by mild flu-like symptoms and diffuse redness of the face with perioral sparing (“slapped‑cheek rash”). However, this patient does not have a rash and her symptoms are consistent with a measles infection, which is not associated with aplastic anemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Glomerular immune complex deposition occurs in glomerulonephritis, which can develop after a streptococcal infection of the throat (e.g., bacterial pharyngitis, scarlet fever) and the skin (e.g., erysipelas). Scarlet fever also presents with fever; however, other expected features, such as tonsillopharyngitis, a white-coated or strawberry-red tongue, and gastrointestinal symptoms, followed by a rash, are absent in this patient. She presents with symptoms suggestive of measles, which is not associated with glomerulonephritis.
