questions.hint: This young girl has a 3-day history of coryza, cough, conjunctivitis (the “3 Cs”), fever, and multiple bluish-white lesions on an erythematous background (suggestive of Koplik spots). She probably did not receive the recommended vaccinations, which, in combination with her presentation, suggests an active measles infection in the prodromal (catarrhal) stage.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of fever and a pruritic rash that started on his trunk and then progressed to his face and extremities. He has not received any childhood vaccinations because his parents believe that they are dangerous. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonbullous impetigo, which can be caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes, is the most common skin infection in children. It is characterized by a localized lesion (most commonly on the face and extremities) that begins as an erythematous papule and progresses to a pustule that may rupture and dry (i.e., honey-colored crusts). Regional lymphadenopathy can also be present. This patient's generalized rash, which is present in all stages (i.e., macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions) on his trunk, face, and extremities, is not consistent with nonbullous impetigo.
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

B) INCORRECT:

Roseola infantum (exanthem subitum or sixth disease), which is primarily caused by HHV-6 and, less frequently, by HHV-7, can manifest with a generalized rash and fever. However, children typically present with a 3–7 day history of persistent high-grade fever (may present as febrile seizures) that rapidly subsides, followed by the development of a rose-pink, nonpruritic, blanching maculopapular rash that begins on the trunk. In contrast, this patient's fever and rash appeared simultaneously. Additional features of roseola infantum may include conjunctivitis, orbital edema, inflammation of the tympanic membranes, lymphadenopathy, upper respiratory tract symptoms, and Nagayama spots, none of which are seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Varicella (chickenpox) is caused by the varicella-zoster virus (HHV-3) and is characterized by fever and a generalized pruritic rash in various stages of healing that typically begins on the trunk and spreads to the face and extremities. Chickenpox is no longer as common in the United States following the introduction of the varicella vaccine in 1995. Children between 12–15 months of age should receive their first dose of the vaccine and a second dose between ages 4–6.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpes zoster (shingles) is caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus which remains dormant in the dorsal root ganglia. It most commonly occurs in adults over the age of 50 years and classically presents as a painful vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution. Fever, headaches, and paresthesias may also occur. This patient's rash, which is present in all stages (i.e., macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions) on his trunk, face, and extremities, is not consistent with herpes zoster.
Image Description:

Multiple, partly confluent vesicles with a strict dermatomal distribution are visible.

This appearance is suggestive of shingles.

E) INCORRECT:

Measles (rubeola) should be considered in an unvaccinated child with fever and a generalized rash. However, the measles rash is typically confluent, nonpruritic, and characteristically begins on the face and moves downward, as opposed to this boy's rash. In addition, the rash is usually preceded by a constellation of symptoms including cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and enanthem with Koplik spots, none of which are seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Rubella (German measles) should be considered in an unvaccinated child with fever and a generalized pruritic rash. However, the rubella rash is typically maculopapular and begins on the face and moves downward (as opposed to this patient's rash) sparing the palms and soles. In addition, rubella is characterized by a prodromal phase in which patients usually present with post-auricular and/or suboccipital lymphadenopathy, neither of which are seen in this child.

G) INCORRECT:

Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which is caused by parvovirus B19, can manifest with fever and a generalized pruritic rash. However, the rash is typically only mildly pruritic and initially appears on the cheeks (“slapped-cheek” rash) before spreading to the trunk and extremities, where it has a lace-like, reticular appearance as it clears. This patient's rash, which is present in all stages (i.e., macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions), is not consistent with erythema infectiosum.
questions.hint: A generalized pruritic rash with simultaneous occurrence of macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions indicates infection with human herpesvirus 3.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 2-day history of mildly pruritic rash on her trunk and extremities. One week ago, she developed a low-grade fever, rhinorrhea, and headache, followed by a facial rash 4 days later. The facial rash did not involve the perioral skin. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash on her lower arms is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rubella (German measles) is a viral exanthematous illness usually seen in unvaccinated children. As in this patient, this condition also causes cold-like symptoms and a maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads distally. The rash, however, is usually nonconfluent and involves the perioral region.

B) INCORRECT:

Measles (rubeola) is a paramyxovirus infection and manifests with a prodromal stage followed by an exanthem stage that is characterized by an erythematous confluent maculopapular rash. As in this patient, the rash starts on the face and extends to the body and is self-limiting. However, the rash of measles does not spare the perioral area and is usually accompanied by a high fever.

C) CORRECT:

The patient's presentation of prodromal low-grade fever and cold‑like symptoms, followed by a facial rash with perioral sparing (“slapped-cheek” appearance) that spreads to the trunk and extremities with a lace-like, reticular pattern, is consistent with erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease. Fifth disease is caused by a parvovirus B19 infection.

This condition is most commonly seen in children aged 5–15 years and is self-limiting, usually resolving in 7–10 days.

D) INCORRECT:

Hand, foot, and mouth disease is a viral illness that is characterized by a pruritic maculopapular and vesicular rash primarily on the hands and feet. Although the rash can manifest with vesicles in the oropharynx, it does not involve the face. Additionally, the cold-like symptoms usually accompany the rash rather than precede it.
Image Description:

Hands and feet of a 36-year-old male patient

Macular and papular lesions are visible on the inner surface of the hands and feet.

The localization in conjunction with the enanthem of the mucous membranes is typical of hand, foot, and mouth disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Roseola (exanthem subitum) is an exanthematous illness caused by the human herpesvirus 6. This condition typically manifests in infants or toddlers with a high fever for 3–7 days that is immediately followed by a patchy maculopapular rash. Opposite of this patient's presentation, the rash seen in exanthem subitum starts on the trunk and can spread to the face and extremities.

F) INCORRECT:

Scarlet fever most commonly occurs in children with streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis and causes a fine, maculopapular rash with a sandpaper‑like texture. The face can be flushed with perioral pallor, which resembles the perioral-sparing rash described in this patient. However, the rash usually starts on the neck, axilla, and groin, and then spreads to the rest of the body.
questions.hint: Complications of this condition include hydrops fetalis in case of intrauterine transmission during pregnancy and aplastic crises in patients with sickle cell disease.

questions.text: A 15-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of the sudden appearance of a rash on her trunk that started 6 hours ago and subsequently spread to her extremities. Four days ago, she was taken to the emergency department because of a high fever and vomiting. She was treated with acetaminophen and discharged the next day. The fever persisted for several days and abated just prior to appearance of the rash. Physical examination shows a rose-colored, blanching, maculopapular rash, and occipital lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease is an acute vasculitis that affects mostly young children of Asian descent. While it also can manifest with high fever, lymphadenopathy, and a rash on the trunk, this patient does not have other typical findings of Kawasaki disease, such as erythema on the hands and feet, conjunctivitis, or mucositis.

B) INCORRECT:

Nonbullous impetigo is a superficial skin infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes, and typically manifests with papules on the face or extremities that may progress to form crusted and oozing pustules (e.g., “honey-colored crusting”). This patient has no such lesions and fever would be unusual for impetigo.

C) INCORRECT:

Scarlet fever is caused by infection with group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (e.g., due to GAS pharyngitis). Scarlet fever would also present with a blanching, maculopapular rash, but the rash has a fine, sandpaper-like texture. More importantly, however, the rash would have been preceded by symptoms of acute tonsillitis, such as a sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and/or enlarged cervical lymph nodes.

D) CORRECT:

Roseola infantum is a self-limited viral exanthem (usually due to HHV-6 and less commonly, HHV-7) that primarily affects infants and young children and is characterized by a high fever for 3–7 days that is immediately followed by a blanching, maculopapular, non-pruritic rash. The rash initially appears on the trunk but may spread to the face and extremities. It is commonly associated with cervical and/or occipital lymphadenopathy and may also cause febrile seizures.

E) INCORRECT:

A drug hypersensitivity reaction can also cause a maculopapular rash, but would typically have a diffuse, random distribution and be pruritic. This patient also does not have any respiratory symptoms (cough, sneezing, airway obstruction), which are common in allergic reactions. Moreover, drug allergies do not cause lymphadenopathy.

F) INCORRECT:

Rubella also presents with a maculopapular rash and lymphadenopathy. However, it typically only causes a low-grade fever, and the rash begins on the face/head and spreads to the trunk. In older patients, it can also present with polyarthritis.

G) INCORRECT:

Measles, also known as rubeola, also presents with a blanching, maculopapular rash and fever in the exanthem stage. However, the exanthem stage is preceded by a prodromal stage that lasts ∼ 4–7 days and is characterized by cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis, which were not present in this patient.

H) INCORRECT:

Erythema infectiosum (also known as fifth disease) is an illness caused by parvovirus B19 that presents with mild cold-like symptoms followed by an exanthem 7–10 days later. In contrast to this patient, the rash starts out on the face with diffuse erythema and perioral sparing (slapped‑cheek rash) and only spreads to the extremities and trunk afterward. A high fever would also be unusual for erythema infectiosum, which may have a low-grade fever during the prodrome phase.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is consistent with an infection caused by human herpes virus 6, also known as exanthem subitum (“sudden exanthem”).

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of pain and stiffness in her hands and wrists and a nonpruritic generalized rash. The stiffness is worst in the morning and improves after 15–20 minutes of activity. She had fever and a runny nose 10 days ago that resolved without treatment. She is sexually active with a male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. She works as an elementary school teacher. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Examination shows swelling, tenderness, and decreased range of motion of the wrists as well as the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. There is a lacy macular rash over the trunk and extremities. Laboratory studies, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate and anti-nuclear antibody and anti-dsDNA serology, show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Common findings in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) include fever and joint pain as seen in this young female patient. However, dermatologic findings of lupus often include a malar rash, photosensitivity, or discoid lupus rather than a self-limited reticular rash on the extremities. In addition, this patient also has normal hemoglobin, normal ESR, negative anti-nuclear antibodies, negative anti-dsDNA, and normal renal function, which would be unlikely in SLE.

B) INCORRECT:

Psoriatic arthritis can present with or without skin or nail findings and can also cause either a symmetrical polyarthritis as in this patient or an asymmetrical oligoarticular arthritis. However, the condition commonly involves the spine, the sacroiliac joint, and the distal interphalangeal joints, none of which are affected in this patient. Furthermore, psoriatic arthritis does not cause a reticular rash on the extremities, and lab values typically show an elevated ESR as psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory condition.

C) CORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 infection, also known as erythema infectiosum or fifth disease, is a common childhood disease that can also affect adults. The disease typically manifests with mild febrile illness, occasionally followed by a maculopapular rash beginning on the perioral areas of the face several days later and spreading to the extremities from there. As the rash clears, it adopts a lacy and reticular pattern, as seen in this patient. More commonly in adults, parvovirus B19 infection may also present with symptoms of symmetric polyarthritis in the fingers, hands, knees, and ankles while the rash can be absent. The disease is usually self-limited and treatment is supportive, involving analgesics and NSAIDs.

D) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis presents with the classic triad of acute onset of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis in roughly a third of cases. Although reactive arthritis can also be associated with fever and a runny nose, joint involvement usually includes asymmetrical migratory polyarthritis in the lower extremities, sacroiliitis, or enthesopathy. Furthermore, the patient does not have conjunctivitis, uveitis, oral lesions, diarrhea, or any urogenital tract symptoms that also present with reactive arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Around 2% of cases of Neisseria gonorrhoeae develop disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI). Although DGI may manifest with fever and polyarthralgia in the hands, this patient is missing other common symptoms such as dermatitis and tenosynovitis. Furthermore, arthritis caused by DGI is a migratory asymmetric arthritis, while this patient has symmetric polyarthritis in her hands and wrists.
Image Description:

A pustule with surrounding erythema is located on the left palm in the area of the 5th metacarpal bone.

F) INCORRECT:

Although this patient had symptoms that could be attributable to rheumatoid arthritis, such as fever and symmetric polyarthralgia in the hands and wrists, this diagnosis is less likely because of her rash, normal ESR, and acute onset. Furthermore, rheumatoid arthritis typically presents with morning stiffness that lasts for more than 30 minutes. If her arthritis symptoms do not resolve within a few weeks, however, she should undergo more specific testing for rheumatoid arthritis.
questions.hint: This young woman with a recent history of flu-like symptoms, a nonpruritic generalized rash, and acute bilateral upper extremity arthralgias likely contracted a self-limited disease given her exposure to young children.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of a 1-day history of a pruritic rash on his trunk and face. Five days ago, he developed low-grade fever, nausea, and diarrhea. Physical examination shows a lace-like erythematous rash on the trunk and face with circumoral pallor. The agent most likely causing symptoms in this patient has selective tropism for which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Certain pathogens (e.g., group A β‑hemolytic streptococci) display tropism for epithelial cells. Infection with GAS can cause scarlet fever, which manifests with an erythematous rash, perioral pallor, and fever, which are seen in this patient, but it would typically also cause pharyngitis and a white or strawberry tongue.

B) INCORRECT:

Certain pathogens (e.g., EBV) display tropism for B lymphocytes. Infection with EBV can cause infectious mononucleosis, a highly contagious condition, which spreads via saliva (hence the name “kissing disease”). EBV infection can manifest with fever and pruritic rash, which are seen in this patient, but acute pharyngitis, tonsillitis, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly would also be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Certain pathogens (e.g., VZV and HIV) display tropism for T lymphocytes. Given this patient's age, he could have chickenpox caused by a primary infection with VZV. Chickenpox typically manifests with a pruritic rash and fever, which are seen here. However, the rash would be more widespread, involving not only the face and trunk, but also the scalp, extremities, oral and urogenital mucosa, palms, and soles. Moreover, a characteristic feature of chickenpox is the simultaneous occurrence of various stages of rash (macules, papules, vesicles, crusted papules), which is not seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

A 7-year-old patient with a pruritic, lace-like erythematous rash on his trunk and face that developed 5 days after a low-grade fever, nausea, and diarrhea most likely has a parvovirus B19 infection. Parvovirus B19 has selective tropism for erythroid progenitor cells. Infection of these cells can result in temporary suspension of erythropoiesis, which leads to transient aplastic crisis.

E) INCORRECT:

Certain pathogens (e.g., VZV, HSV-1, or HSV-2) display tropism for sensory neuronal cells and remain dormant within sensory nerve ganglia following primary infection. A primary infection with VZV typically manifests with a pruritic rash and fever, which are seen in this patient. However, the rash would be more widespread, involving not only the face and trunk, but also the scalp, extremities, oral and urogenital mucosa, palms, and soles. Herpes simplex virus infections typically only cause localized symptoms (aphthous stomatitis, herpes labialis, or herpes genitalis).

F) INCORRECT:

Certain pathogens (e.g., the measles virus and CMV) display tropism for monocytes. While measles typically manifests with conjunctivitis, coryza, and cough, followed by sudden development of a high fever, malaise, and an erythematous, maculopapular rash, this patient presents with low-grade fever and a lace-like erythematous rash with perioral sparing. CMV infection usually remains asymptomatic in immunocompetent patients.
questions.hint: Infection with this pathogen during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because of a 2-day history of fever and malaise. Yesterday, she developed a rash on her chest that has since spread to her shoulders, arms, neck, face, and stomach area. She tries her best not to scratch her body but describes the rash as “very itchy.” She has not had nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Her mother had measles during childhood but no other rashes. She has only received immunization for hepatitis B because her mother, who has never been vaccinated, is skeptical about “the whole vaccination thing.” The girl appears lethargic. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 126/84 mm Hg. Examination of the skin shows a papular rash with vesicles and crusted lesions. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Three days ago, the family visited the patient's 10-day-old brother at the neonatal intensive care unit. He was born at 31 weeks' gestation and weighed 1390 g (3 lb 1 oz) at birth. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for the patient's brother?

choices.text: Observe and reevaluate the next day

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A watchful waiting approach is indicated in patients who have a low risk of developing complications from chickenpox. Because premature newborns are at increased risk of developing complications from VZV infection, a watchful waiting approach is not appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used to treat chickenpox in individuals who are at high risk of developing complications, such as immunocompromised patients, unvaccinated adolescents ≥ 13 years of age, adults, and individuals on long-term salicylates therapy. This patient's newborn brother does not yet have chickenpox; therefore, treatment with antiviral therapy is not indicated. In this case, the focus must be on disease prevention.

C) INCORRECT:

A live attenuated vaccine is used to actively immunize against varicella. Following varicella exposure, postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) with active immunization is indicated for immunocompetent individuals who are not pregnant and not yet immune against varicella (either as a result of previous VZV infection or completed routine childhood varicella immunization); the varicella vaccine would be used as PEP for this patient's mother. However, because guidelines do not permit the use of the varicella vaccine before the age of 12 months, a different method of PEP is indicated for this patient's brother.

D) CORRECT:

The use of VZV immunoglobulin (passive immunization) as postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) for chickenpox is indicated in premature neonates born after 28 weeks' gestation to mothers with no evidence of immunity to VZV, as seen here (this patient's mother has never had chickenpox). PEP prevents disease onset or mitigates the course of the disease and must be given within 10 days following exposure (ideally within 4 days). Other indications for passive postexposure immunoprophylaxis include newborns born before 28 weeks' gestation regardless of the mother's immunity status, pregnant women or immunosuppressed patients with no evidence of immunity to VZV, and newborns whose mother was infected between 5 days before and up to 2 days after birth.

E) INCORRECT:

Conjugate polysaccharide vaccines include vaccines against Haemophilus influenzae serotype b, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Salmonella typhi. Active immunization against chickenpox is performed with a different type of vaccine. The H. influenzae serotype b (Hib) vaccine and S. pneumoniae conjugate vaccine (PCV15, PCV20) would be administered to the patient's brother as a part of routine immunization but only at 2 months of age. The N. meningitidis conjugate vaccine is only indicated at 11–12 years of age and the S. typhi conjugate vaccine is not a part of the routine immunization schedule.

F) INCORRECT:

Measurement of specific anti-VZV IgG titers is performed as part of antenatal care for pregnant women who have not had chickenpox or not received the varicella vaccine in order to determine immunity against VZV and the need for post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) against varicella. In cases of varicella exposure in preterm neonates born to a mother with no evidence of immunity to VZV, guidelines do not recommend serological testing before administering PEP.
questions.hint: A generalized pruritic rash that consists of papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions in conjunction with fever, malaise, and incomplete immunizations strongly suggests chickenpox. Hospitalized premature newborns are at increased risk of complications from varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 5-day history of a generalized rash. The rash started on the cheeks and has since spread to the rest of the body. His mother states that the rash is more prominent after he plays in their garden. Last week, he had a fever for 3 days and was treated with over-the-counter acetaminophen. The rash appeared after the fever resolved. His mother is concerned that he is allergic to acetaminophen. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 91/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/63 mm Hg. Examination of the skin shows erythema of the cheeks with perioral sparing. There is a diffuse, erythematous, reticular rash on the trunk and limbs. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8000/mm3, and platelet count is 270,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Throat swab and empiric oral penicillin V therapy
Echocardiography, intravenous immunoglobulin, and aspirin therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A throat swab and empiric oral penicillin V therapy are appropriate management steps for scarlet fever, which can manifest with a rash that appears after the onset of fever. However, the rash seen in scarlet fever typically has a sandpaper texture, begins on the neck (not the cheeks) before spreading, and spares the palms and soles. Scarlet fever also causes pharyngitis and cervical lymphadenopathy, which this patient does not have.

B) INCORRECT:

A short course of oral prednisone is used to treat parvovirus B19-associated arthritis. Although this child has a parvovirus B19 infection (erythema infectiosum), there is no evidence of associated arthritis, which typically manifests as arthralgia with symmetric, nondestructive polyarthritis in the fingers, hands, knees, and ankles. Parvovirus B19-associated arthritis is uncommon in children, occurring in < 10% of cases.

C) INCORRECT:

In immunocompetent patients, serology for pathogen-specific antibody titers (e.g., IgG or IgM antibodies against parvovirus B19) is performed if the diagnosis is unclear (nonclassic presentation) or definitive etiologic diagnosis is necessary to determine the next steps in management. However, this patient presents with classic clinical features of erythema infectiosum, management recommendations for which are not affected by serologic confirmation.

D) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography, intravenous immunoglobulin, and aspirin therapy are appropriate management steps for Kawasaki disease, which typically manifests with fever and a rash. However, the fever associated with Kawasaki disease typically persists for > 5 days, and the rash usually starts on the trunk, not the face. In addition, this patient does not have other typical findings of Kawasaki disease, such as conjunctivitis, stomatitis with chapped lips and a strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy.

E) CORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up are sufficient, as erythema infectiosum is typically a self-limited condition in immunocompetent children. In < 10% of children, parvovirus B19-associated arthritis can occur, which typically manifests in the joints of the fingers, hands, knees, and ankles and resolves after 3–4 weeks. Analgesics and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents can be used supportively.

Though parvovirus B19 infection in children is usually self-limited, infection in pregnancy can cause severe anemia, fetal hydrops, and fetal demise.
questions.hint: This patient's flu-like illness and subsequent slapped-cheek rash on the face that consequently spread to the body is consistent with a diagnosis of erythema infectiosum, which is caused by infection with parvovirus B19.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department in late summer shortly after an episode of sudden loss of consciousness with uncontrolled shaking of the entire body and facial twitching. Her mother reports that the event lasted for about 2 minutes and that her daughter quickly returned to normal afterward. For the past 24 hours, the girl has had a fever and a sore throat. She has no history of serious illness. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears weak but is alert, oriented, and responds appropriately in short sentences. Her temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 100/66 mm Hg. Capillary refill time is 2 seconds. Examination of the oral cavity shows the findings in the photograph. The remainder of the examination, including neurologic examination, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin and ceftriaxone are the empiric therapy of choice for patients between 1 month and 50 years of age with suspected bacterial meningitis. While meningitis can manifest with fever and seizures, further features such as headache, nuchal rigidity, and photophobia are also expected. This patient with a normal neurologic examination more likely had a simple febrile seizure (a generalized seizure lasting < 15 minutes) due to herpangina, for which antibiotic therapy is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the head is indicated in patients with suspected meningitis and signs of elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., focal neurologic deficits) prior to a lumbar puncture, or after a complex febrile seizure to rule out structural causes. While meningitis can manifest with fever and new-onset seizures, further features such as headache, nuchal rigidity, and photophobia are also expected. This patient with a normal neurologic examination more likely had a simple febrile seizure (i.e., a generalized seizure lasting < 15 minutes) due to herpangina; therefore, a CT scan of the head is not appropriate.

C) CORRECT:

Simple febrile seizures occur among children 6 months to 5 years of age, are generalized tonic-clonic seizures, last < 15 minutes, do not recur within 24 hours, and are usually followed by a quick return to a normal state without focal neurologic deficits. Simple febrile seizures do not require specific diagnostic workup if the cause of fever is known and neurologic examination is unremarkable. Diagnosis of herpangina is established clinically and treatment consists of supportive care only, since the condition is typically self-limited. Antipyretic therapy (NSAIDs such as ibuprofen, or acetaminophen) is the treatment of choice for symptomatic relief of herpangina as well as for fever reduction after a febrile seizure. Children with herpangina who are dehydrated (as evidenced by, e.g., prolonged capillary refill time) due to decreased oral intake should be admitted to hospital and receive parenteral fluids.
Image Description:

Several small vesicles and partially confluent yellow-white ulcers with an erythematous rim are visible on the inflamed soft palate.

This is the typical appearance of herpangina, an infection caused by the coxsackie A virus. The enanthem typically starts as painful, herpes-like vesicles on the oropharynx that then break down to form shallow, painful ulcers.

D) INCORRECT:

A throat swab for a rapid group A streptococcus (GAS) antigen detection test and empiric penicillin therapy are indicated in patients with suspected GAS tonsillopharyngitis, which also manifests with sudden onset of fever, sore throat, and tonsillopharyngeal erythema. However, GAS tonsillopharyngitis is typically associated with gray-white tonsillar exudates and edema rather than multiple small, white vesicles like the ones seen here. This patient presents with herpangina, for which a throat swab is not required and penicillin therapy is ineffective.
Image Description:

Oral cavity of a child presenting with fever, dysphagia, and tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy

The pharyngeal tonsils are enlarged, erythematous, edematous, and have streaks of mucopurulent discharge bilaterally.

This is the typical appearance of bilateral acute tonsillitis.

E) INCORRECT:

A lumbar puncture (LP) is indicated in patients with suspected meningitis or encephalitis, both of which can manifest with fever and new-onset seizures. However, further features (e.g., headache, nuchal rigidity, photophobia, altered mental status, focal neurologic deficits) are also expected. This patient with a normal neurologic examination more likely had a simple febrile seizure (a generalized seizure lasting < 15 minutes) due to herpangina; LP is not indicated in patients who appear well with a known cause of fever.

F) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir therapy is indicated in herpetic gingivostomatitis, which also manifests with painful, small oral lesions, fever, and sore throat. In addition, herpetic gingivostomatitis can be complicated by herpes simplex (HSV) encephalitis, which can also manifest with seizures. However, the lesions in herpetic gingivostomatitis are commonly located on the anterior oropharynx, tongue, lips, and perioral skin (as opposed to the posterior oropharynx in this child) and are preceded by a prodromal phase with several days of fever and malaise. Furthermore, this patient does not have any other expected symptoms of HSV encephalitis (e.g., altered mental status, focal neurologic deficits). More likely this patient had a simple febrile seizure due to herpangina, for which acyclovir is not indicated.
Image Description:

Multiple red erosions can be seen on the lips. Intact vesicles with surrounding erythema are visible on the tongue.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpetic gingivostomatitis.
questions.hint: The photograph shows multiple small, white vesicles and an erythematous rim on the inner lip, uvula, soft palate, tonsillar pillars, and buccal mucosa of the lip. These findings are characteristic of herpangina, a Coxsackie A virus infection that is typically accompanied by high fever and, therefore, poses a risk for febrile seizures.

questions.text: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the office by her mother because of a generalized nonpruritic rash for 2 days. The rash began on her trunk and spread to her extremities. Five days ago, she was taken to the emergency department for fever of 40.5°C (104.9°F) and a 1-minute generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The mother says the fever resolved abruptly. The patient was born at term and has no history of serious illness. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F) and pulse is 120/min. Examination shows a maculopapular rash that blanches on pressure. A photograph of the rash is shown. Posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease is an acute vasculitis that manifests with high fever and a rash on the trunk. However, the patient is lacking other typical findings of Kawasaki disease, such as erythema on the hands and feet, conjunctivitis, and mucositis.

B) CORRECT:

Roseola infantum (i.e., exanthem subitum) is a disease caused by the human herpesvirus 6 that primarily affects infants and young children. The infection is characterized by high fever, which ends abruptly after three to seven days (“three-day fever”), followed by the sudden appearance of a truncal rash that may spread to the face and extremities. Cervical and/or occipital lymphadenopathy are often present. Febrile seizures are a possible complication of infection; however, most patients recover from these seizures without any adverse outcome. Treatment is symptomatic as the disease is self-limiting.

See “Common causes of infectious rash in children” table.

C) INCORRECT:

Measles also manifests with a blanching, maculopapular rash, and fever in the exanthem stage. However, the exanthem stage is preceded by a prodromal stage that lasts ∼ 4–7 days and is characterized by cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis, which was not present in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Fifth disease is an illness caused by parvovirus B19 that manifests with a mild cold-like prodrome that is followed by a maculopapular rash with a slapped-cheek appearance after approximately 7–10 days. Although this infant has a maculopapular rash, it does not resemble a slapped-cheek appearance. Additionally, she had a high fever rather than a mild fever that would be expected in the prodrome phase.

E) INCORRECT:

Rubella also manifests with a maculopapular rash and postauricular lymphadenopathy. However, rubella typically only causes a mild fever, and the exanthem's course is typically independent of the timing of the fever. Additionally, the rash begins on the face/head and spreads to the trunk. In older patients, rubella often also manifests with polyarthritis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a nonpruritic, blanching, maculopapular rash that developed immediately after the abrupt cessation of a high fever.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the office because of a progressive rash for 2 days. The rash started on the face and now involves the trunk and extremities. Over the past 4 days, he has had a mild sore throat, red, itchy eyes, and headache. He was born at term and has been healthy except for recurrent episodes of tonsillitis. Two weeks ago, he was treated for tonsillitis that resolved with penicillin therapy. He emigrated with his family from Japan 3 weeks ago. His immunization status is unknown. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. There is a nonconfluent, pink maculopapular rash over the torso and extremities. His palms and soles show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measles typically manifest in two stages. The prodromal stage is characterized by a classic triad of coryza, cough, and conjunctivitis in combination with Koplik spots. It is followed by an exanthem stage in which patients usually develop a high fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, and a maculopapular, blanching, partially confluent exanthem that spreads from the face to the entire body. This patient's low-grade fever, postauricular lymphadenopathy, good general condition, and nonconfluent rash are not characteristic of measles.
Image Description:

Multiple maculopapular blanching and partially confluent patches are disseminated over the head, neck, and back of this young patient.

These findings are consistent with a desquamating rash, which can occur after fading of the first erythematous exanthema, caused by an infection with the measles virus.

B) INCORRECT:

Exanthem subitum usually manifests in patients between 6 months and 2 years of age, with almost all children being seropositive by the age of three. The typical presentation begins with a febrile phase, with abrupt onset high fever, cervical and/or occipital lymphadenopathy, inflamed tympanic membranes, and papular enanthem on the uvula and soft palate (Nagayama spots). After 2–3 days, patients subsequently develop a sudden decrease in temperature and a patchy, rose-pink, confluent, blanching, maculopapular exanthem that begins on the trunk and can spread to the face and extremities. The rash usually fades within a few hours to 2 days and can therefore easily go unnoticed. The patient's age, history of a progressive rash for 2 days, and the finding of a nonconfluent exanthem make another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Photograph of a 9-month-old infant with recent high fever

A patchy, macular exanthem is visible on the trunk, neck, and behind the ears. Symptoms developed after the fever resolved.

These features are consistent with roseola infantum.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with mild nonspecific symptoms (sore throat, low-grade fever, conjunctivitis, headache) and post-auricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy, followed by a nonconfluent, pink maculopapular rash, all of which suggest Rubella infection. The exanthem typically begins on the head and spreads to the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. During the prodromal phase, a maculopapular enanthem on the soft palate (Forchheimer sign) may be present.

Rubella was officially eliminated in the US in 2004 by widespread vaccination. However, sporadic cases may occur in unimmunized individuals with a recent history of migration to the US or travel to a country with a higher prevalence of the disease. While rubella is usually self-limited and has a benign course, infection during pregnancy can lead to congenital rubella syndrome, with cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss, and heart defects in the neonate.

D) INCORRECT:

Allergic drug reactions often present as a type IV hypersensitivity with a red, blanching maculopapular rash beginning on the head, then spreading to the trunk and extremities. While almost any oral medication can result in an allergic reaction, common causes are allopurinol, phenytoin, penicillin, and sulfa antibiotics. The exanthem usually begins 5–14 days after the medication has been initiated and may involve the palms, soles, and mucous membranes. Although this patient was treated with penicillin two weeks ago, the presence of lymphadenopathy without pruritus makes another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Upper body of a man presenting with a severely pruritic rash after getting a henna tattoo on the right arm

An erythematous papulovesicular rash is visible over the chest and arms. The rash is most severe around the henna tattoo, which appears markedly erythematous.

This is the typical appearance of allergic contact dermatitis.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with scarlet fever, an initial phase with fever, tonsillopharyngitis, and gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea) is usually followed by a scarlet‑colored maculopapular, blanching exanthem with a sandpaper-like texture. The rash typically begins on the neck and subsequently spreads to the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. Characteristic findings of scarlet fever are Pastia's lines, perioral pallor, and a strawberry tongue. After resolution of the rash, the skin typically desquamates in flakes, exposing new and tender epidermis. The examination findings presented in the case above are not consistent with those of scarlet fever.
Image Description:

The typical scarlet-colored, fine, maculopapular exanthem of scarlet fever is seen on the right arm. Flushed cheeks and perioral pallor are also evident.
questions.hint: Older patients with this condition often present with polyarthritis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 11-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of fever, cough, and a runny nose. During this period, he has also had pink, itchy eyes. He has not yet received any routine childhood vaccinations. The patient lives at a foster home with ten other refugees; two have similar symptoms. He appears anxious and is sweating. His temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctivitis of both eyes. There are multiple, 2-mm-sized, bluish-gray papules with an erythematous rim on the buccal mucosa and the soft palate. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aplastic crisis may occur as a complication in patients with erythema infectiosum, which is characterized by a prodrome of mild flu-like symptoms followed by diffuse redness of the face with perioral sparing (“slapped‑cheek rash”) without any enanthem. This patient's clinical features are consistent with a measles infection, which does not cause aplastic anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Glomerulonephritis can develop after a streptococcal infection such as scarlet fever. While the prodrome of scarlet fever also manifests with fever, other expected features include tonsillopharyngitis, a white-coated or strawberry-red tongue, cervical lymphadenopathy, and/or gastrointestinal symptoms. This patient presents with symptoms suggestive of measles, which is not associated with glomerulonephritis.

C) CORRECT:

Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare complication of measles infection. SSPE usually develops at least 7 years after the initial infection with measles and is characterized by dementia, myoclonus, and epilepsy, leading to coma and death. Diagnosis is established based on electroencephalography and cerebral spinal fluid analysis. Although there is no treatment available for SSPE, both measles infection, and SSPE are typically prevented by a live, attenuated virus in combination with the mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine, which is given during childhood.

In addition to SSPE, measles can also cause acute complications like bacterial superinfection (otitis media, pneumonia), (viral) giant-cell pneumonia, gastroenteritis, or acute encephalitis that may lead to acute disseminated encephalomyelitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) is associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. Acute EBV infection (infectious mononucleosis) is characterized by fever, fatigue, tonsillopharyngitis, bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. This patient presents with measles, which is not associated with NHL.
Image Description:

Enlarged, inflamed tonsil (green overlay) with gray-white deposits (white outline) in a patient with infectious mononucleosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) may occur as a complication of rubella, which typically manifests with a prodrome of fever, conjunctivitis, a petechial enanthem of the soft palate (Forchheimer sign), and postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. Rarely, ITP occurs following measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccination but ITP is not a complication of measles infection.
questions.hint: This unvaccinated patient has a 3-day history of coryza, cough, conjunctivitis (the “3 Cs”), fever, and multiple bluish-gray lesions on an erythematous background (Koplik spots), all of which suggest an active measles infection in the prodromal (catarrhal) stage.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after the sudden onset of a rash that started on the face and behind the ears and progressed to the trunk and extremities. Over the past week, he has had a runny nose, a cough, and red, crusty eyes. Immunization records are unavailable. His temperature is 40.0°C (104°F). Examination shows generalized lymphadenopathy and a blanching, partially confluent maculopapular exanthema. Administration of which of the following is most likely to prevent complications in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Valacyclovir is used to treat VZV and HSV infections. Primary HSV infection in children typically presents as gingivostomatitis with bloody gingival ulcerations and mucosal blisters. Cervical lymphadenopathy, but not generalized lymphadenopathy, may be present. VZV infection (chickenpox) presents with a widespread rash that starts on the trunk, and eventually spreads to the face, scalp, and extremities as opposed to the progression from head to trunk seen in this patient. In VZV infection, the various stages of the rash typically occur simultaneously.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral penicillin V is used to treat various diseases, including scarlet fever, which also manifests with a blanching, maculopapular rash. However, in scarlet fever, the rash would have a sandpaper-like texture and be most prominent in flexural areas. In addition, scarlet fever is characterized by a history of pharyngitis (sore throat), flushed cheeks with perioral pallor, and a characteristic white-coated or strawberry-red tongue

C) CORRECT:

While there is no curative treatment for measles, the administration of vitamin A (retinol) can help prevent complications such as otitis media, viral pneumonia, encephalitis, and subacute sclerosing panencephalitis. Vitamin A enhances the barrier function and immunity of the ocular, respiratory, and gastrointestinal epithelium. Lower serum levels of vitamin A are associated with a more severe and prolonged course of the disease. The CDC recommends administration to children with severe measles, while the WHO and the American Academy of Pediatrics Red Book recommend administration to all children with measles.

The small white or bluish-white spot on the buccal mucosa (Koplik spots) that are pathognomonic for measles typically appear in the prodromal phase of the disease. Perhaps this patient had Koplik spots, but they typically fade as the rash appears.

D) INCORRECT:

While the MMR vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine, it has no benefit during the exanthem phase of measles and is, in fact, contraindicated if the child has a high fever, as in this case. MMR vaccine can be administered within 72 hours of exposure to measles in immunocompetent patients (postexposure prophylaxis) or in nonresponders to vaccination as determined by serologic testing.

E) INCORRECT:

IVIG can be used as postexposure prophylaxis (within 6 days of exposure) for measles in infants younger than 12 months of age, pregnant women without evidence of measles immunity, and people with severely compromised immune systems. As, in this patient, the disease is already in the exanthem stage, it is now too late for postexposure prophylaxis. Another possible indication for IVIG would be Kawasaki disease, but the child does not have the characteristic strawberry tongue and rash with palmar and plantar desquamation.
questions.hint: Coryza, cough, and conjunctivitis followed by maculopapular, blanching, partially confluent exanthema are characteristic of measles.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl is brought to the office by her parents because of a 2-day history of reticular rash on her trunk and extremities. One week ago, she developed a low-grade fever, rhinorrhea, and headache, followed by a facial rash resembling flushed cheeks. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash on her lower arms is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rubella (German measles) is a viral exanthematous illness usually seen in unvaccinated children. As in this patient, this condition also causes cold-like symptoms and a maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads distally. The rash, however, is usually nonconfluent and involves the perioral region.

B) INCORRECT:

Measles (rubeola) is a paramyxovirus infection and manifests with a prodromal stage followed by an exanthem stage that is characterized by an erythematous confluent maculopapular rash. As in this patient, the rash starts on the face and extends to the body and is self-limiting. However, the rash of measles does not spare the perioral area and is usually accompanied by a high fever.

C) CORRECT:

The patient's presentation of prodromal low-grade fever and cold‑like symptoms, followed by a facial rash with perioral sparing (“slapped-cheek” appearance) that spreads to the trunk and extremities with a lace-like, reticular pattern, is consistent with erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease. Fifth disease is caused by a parvovirus B19 infection.

This condition is most commonly seen in children aged 5–15 years and is self-limiting, usually resolving in 7–10 days.

D) INCORRECT:

Roseola (exanthem subitum) is an exanthematous illness caused by the human herpesvirus 6. This condition typically manifests in infants or toddlers with a high fever for 3–7 days that is immediately followed by a patchy maculopapular rash. Opposite of this patient's presentation, the rash seen in exanthem subitum starts on the trunk and can spread to the face and extremities.

E) INCORRECT:

Scarlet fever most commonly occurs in children with streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis and causes a fine, maculopapular rash with a sandpaper‑like texture. The face can be flushed with perioral pallor, which resembles the perioral-sparing rash described in this patient. However, the rash usually starts on the neck, axilla, and groin, and then spreads to the rest of the body.
questions.hint: Complications of this condition include hydrops fetalis in case of intrauterine transmission during pregnancy and aplastic crises in patients with sickle cell disease.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has a low-grade fever, sore throat, oral vesicular lesions, and a nonpruritic rash on his buttocks, hands, and feet shown in the photograph. Which of the following is the most likely infectious agent?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gingivostomatitis and pharyngitis due to herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) can present with fever, sore throat, and vesicular oral lesions. Although herpetic gingivostomatitis is not usually associated with a rash, HSV-1 infection can trigger erythema multiforme (EM). EM, which typically begins on the extremities before spreading to the palms and soles, can also present as a papulovesicular rash. However, EM also characteristically presents with target lesions, which are absent in this patient.
Image Description:

Multiple circular lesions with a central papule and raised edges (also called “target lesions”), surrounded by a lighter edematous area, are visible on the anterior aspect of the thighs.

This is the typical appearance of erythema multiforme.

B) INCORRECT:

The varicella-zoster virus causes chickenpox, which can present with fever, sore throat, and vesicular lesions on the skin as well as oral mucosa. However, the rash of chickenpox typically starts on the trunk and spreads to the face and scalp; the palms and soles are less commonly involved. Also, the lesions are very pruritic and have a polymorphous appearance because the different stages of development (macules, papules, vesicles, erosions, crusts) are seen simultaneously.
Image Description:

A diffuse rash is seen in various stages of lesion evolution (starry-sky appearance), with mainly ruptured vesicles and crusted erosions seen here.

These findings are typical for chickenpox.

C) CORRECT:

Coxsackie A virus can cause hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), which presents with a nonpruritic papulovesicular rash on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. Oral vesicles can easily rupture and cause painful ulcers. In some cases, the arms, legs, and buttocks are also affected. The illness is typically self-limiting. Coxsackie A virus can also cause pharyngitis and herpangina.

Unlike coxsackie A virus, coxsackie B virus does not cause oral or cutaneous disease. It instead causes acute myocarditis, pericarditis, and pleurodynia.

D) INCORRECT:

Rubella typically presents with fever, sore throat, and a rash. However, the rubella exanthem is maculopapular rather than vesicular and it typically begins on the face before spreading caudally with sparing of the palms and soles. Examination of the oral cavity can sometimes reveal palatal petechiae (Forchheimer spots) but oral vesicles would not be expected.
Image Description:

A nonconfluent, pink, maculopapular rash is visible across this infant's trunk and extremities.

E) INCORRECT:

In children, parvovirus B19 causes erythema infectiosum, which can present with fever, sore throat, and a nonpruritic rash that appears a few days after the onset of fever. However, the rash of erythema infectiosum is characterized by malar erythema (“slapped cheek” appearance), circumoral pallor, and lace-like or reticular lesions on the trunk. Neither vesicular lesions nor the involvement of palms and soles would be expected.
Image Description:

The cheeks are bright red (slapped-cheek rash) and a diffuse, red, confluent rash with macules and papules is visible over the body of this infant.

This is the characteristic cutaneous appearance of erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which is caused by infection with parvovirus B19.
questions.hint: A rash on the hands, feet, and mouth is typical of this pediatric febrile exanthem.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the office by his father because of a 3-day history of generalized rash. The rash is not pruritic. He has no cough. He has had a fever and a sore throat for 4 days. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F). Examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. The tongue is bright red. There is tonsillar erythema with exudates. A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The monospot test can be used to support the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis (IM). This patient has fever, tonsillitis, and cervical lymphadenopathy which can also be seen in IM. Patients with IM who are treated with amoxicillin may present with a maculopapular rash. However, IM typically affects adolescents and frequently manifests with additional symptoms, e.g., splenomegaly and abdominal pain, making IM unlikely in this patient.

In addition, the monospot test is not used as a confirmatory test in IM because it carries a high risk of false positive and false negative results.

B) INCORRECT:

Detection of elevated antistreptolysin O and anti‑deoxyribonuclease B titers can be used to diagnose streptococcal infection retrospectively, but they are of little use in determining the initial diagnosis or the appropriate treatment. These titers are more helpful when investigating potential complications such as rheumatic fever and post‑streptococcal glomerulonephritis after the initial infection has already subsided.

C) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography may be performed to evaluate for coronary artery aneurysm, a complication of Kawasaki disease. Although Kawasaki disease should always be considered in a young child presenting with fever and a rash, this patient does not have other characteristic features, such as erythema and edema of the hands and feet, bilateral conjunctivitis, and oropharyngeal mucositis with cracked lips. The erythematous maculopapular rash, perioral pallor, and exudative tonsillitis seen in this patient make scarlet fever the more likely diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Detection of IgM antibodies may be performed to diagnose many viral illnesses (e.g., measles-specific IgM antibodies). This patient presents with fever, lymphadenopathy, and generalized rash, which are also features of measles. However, measles infection is typically characterized by a prodromal stage (coryza, cough, conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots) followed by erythematous maculopapular, blanching, and partially confluent exanthem. Moreover, IgM antibodies are not typically measured in the work-up of suspected scarlet fever, which requires another diagnostic test.

E) CORRECT:

Scarlet fever is caused by group A streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes or GAS), which produce erythrogenic scarlet fever exotoxins. A rapid streptococcal antigen test provides immediate detection of GAS and can be performed with a throat swab at the point of care (e.g., in the office or emergency department). If the initial result is positive, antibiotic treatment with oral penicillin V should be initiated. If negative, a follow-up test with a throat culture, which is the gold standard for confirmation of GAS infection, is needed.
questions.hint: This patient presents with exudative tonsillitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, a strawberry tongue, flushed cheeks with perioral pallor, and an erythematous maculopapular rash that appeared one day after the onset of fever. These findings are characteristic of scarlet fever.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with a generalized rash for 2 days. He has also had a fever and sore throat for 3 days. The rash involves his whole body and is not pruritic. He has not received any routine childhood vaccinations. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F) and pulse is 102/min. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and a flushed face except around his mouth. A diffuse, maculopapular, erythematous rash that blanches with pressure is seen over the trunk with a linear, petechial appearance in the axilla and groin. Oropharyngeal examination shows pharyngeal erythema with a red beefy tongue. Which of the following is the most likely sequela of this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery aneurysms can occur as a complication of Kawasaki disease, a condition that should certainly be considered in a child presenting with fever, rash, and a strawberry tongue. However, this patient does not have other characteristic features, such as erythema and edema of the hands and feet, bilateral conjunctivitis, and oropharyngeal mucositis with cracked lips. Moreover, Kawasaki disease is a clinical diagnosis and requires the presence of a fever lasting for at least 5 days. The perioral pallor and Pastia lines seen here make scarlet fever the more likely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic anemia is a very rare complication of fifth disease (parvovirus B19 infection). Patients with fifth disease usually present similarly to the patient in this case, with flu-like symptoms, an exanthem on trunk and extremities, and a “slapped-cheek” rash with perioral sparing. However, this patient's pharyngitis, strawberry tongue, and Pastia lines are not typical of fifth disease and instead suggest scarlet fever.

C) INCORRECT:

Infectious mononucleosis (IM) is associated with several neoplasias, including Hodgkin lymphoma, Burkitt lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and hairy leukoplakia. IM can present with many symptoms that are similar to the ones seen in this patient such as fever, pharyngitis, and, occasionally, a maculopapular rash (usually following the administration of an aminopenicillin). However, other common features of IM such as splenomegaly, cervical lymphadenopathy, and exudative tonsillitis are absent in this patient. Perioral pallor and an erythematous tongue suggest another diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Postinfectious glomerulonephritis (or poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, PSGN) is a complication of group A streptococcal infections, such as tonsillopharyngitis, scarlet fever, and, less commonly, skin infections. This inflammatory sequela typically occurs approx. 1–6 weeks following an acute infection and is caused by immune complex deposition within the glomerular basement membrane, which leads to complement activation and subsequent destruction of the glomeruli. PSGN manifests with nephritic syndrome, which in most cases is self-limited and requires only supportive treatment.

Antibiotic treatment for group A streptococcal infection (e.g., with penicillin V) can decrease the risk of acute rheumatic fever but does not appear to lower the risk of PSGN.

E) INCORRECT:

Encephalitis is a dangerous late complication of measles or chickenpox. Because this patient has not received the recommended childhood vaccinations, this patient is at increased risk of developing several diseases, including measles and chickenpox. However, the rash typical of measles is usually preceded by coryza, cough and conjunctivitis (the “3 Cs”) and an enanthem of the buccal mucosa (Koplik spots), all of which are absent in this patient. Chickenpox, moreover, is notable for severely pruritic rash with macules that rapidly develop into papules and vesicles. Sore throat, perioral pallor, Pastia lines, and a strawberry tongue suggest scarlet fever.
questions.hint: Sore throat and fever followed by a diffuse, maculopapular, blanching rash with perioral pallor and a strawberry tongue indicate scarlet fever. The rash of scarlet fever is typically more marked in skin creases (e.g., axilla, groin) and has a linear, petechial appearance known as Pastia lines.

questions.text: You are seeing a 9-month-old girl brought to your clinic by her mother because of a generalized nonpruritic rash for 2 days. The rash started on her trunk and spread to her extremities. Five days ago, she was evaluated in the emergency department for a fever of 40.5°C and a 1-minute generalized tonic-clonic seizure. Her mother reports that the fever resolved abruptly. She was born at term and has no history of serious illness. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is now 37.2°C and pulse is 120/min. On examination, she has a maculopapular rash that blanches on pressure. A photograph of the rash is provided. Posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is present. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease is an acute vasculitis that manifests with high fever and a rash on the trunk. However, the patient is lacking other typical findings of Kawasaki disease, such as erythema on the hands and feet, conjunctivitis, and mucositis.

B) INCORRECT:

Measles also manifests with a blanching, maculopapular rash, and fever in the exanthem stage. However, the exanthem stage is preceded by a prodromal stage that lasts ∼ 4–7 days and is characterized by cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis, which was not present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Fifth disease is an illness caused by parvovirus B19 that manifests with a mild cold-like prodrome that is followed by a maculopapular rash with a slapped-cheek appearance after approximately 7–10 days. Although this infant has a maculopapular rash, it does not resemble a slapped-cheek appearance. Additionally, she had a high fever rather than a mild fever that would be expected in the prodrome phase.

D) INCORRECT:

Rubella also manifests with a maculopapular rash and postauricular lymphadenopathy. However, rubella typically only causes a mild fever, and the exanthem's course is typically independent of the timing of the fever. Additionally, the rash begins on the face/head and spreads to the trunk. In older patients, rubella often also manifests with polyarthritis.

E) CORRECT:

Roseola infantum (i.e., exanthem subitum) is a disease caused by the human herpesvirus 6 that primarily affects infants and young children. The infection is characterized by high fever, which ends abruptly after three to five days (“three-day fever”), followed by the sudden appearance of a truncal rash that may spread to the face and extremities. Cervical and/or occipital lymphadenopathy are often present. Febrile seizures are a possible complication of infection; however, most patients recover from these seizures without any adverse outcome. Treatment is symptomatic as the disease is self-limiting.

See “Overview of infectious rashes in childhood” table.

Key learning point: Roseola infantum is characterized by high fever that resolves abruptly, followed by a blanching maculopapular rash starting on the trunk, and is caused by human herpesvirus 6.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a nonpruritic, blanching, maculopapular rash that developed immediately after the abrupt cessation of a high fever.

questions.text: You are seeing an 11-year-old boy in the emergency department who has a 3-day history of fever, cough, and runny nose. He has also developed pink, itchy eyes during this time. He has not received any routine childhood vaccinations. He lives in a foster home with ten other refugees, two of whom have similar symptoms. He appears anxious and is sweating. His temperature is 39.2°C, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Examination reveals conjunctivitis in both eyes and multiple 2-mm bluish-gray papules with an erythematous rim on the buccal mucosa and soft palate. This patient is at increased risk for which one of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) may occur as a complication of rubella, which typically manifests with a prodrome of fever, conjunctivitis, a petechial enanthem of the soft palate (Forchheimer sign), and postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. Rarely, ITP occurs following measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccination but ITP is not a complication of measles infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Glomerulonephritis can develop after a streptococcal infection such as scarlet fever. While the prodrome of scarlet fever also manifests with fever, other expected features include tonsillopharyngitis, a white-coated or strawberry-red tongue, cervical lymphadenopathy, and/or gastrointestinal symptoms. This patient presents with symptoms suggestive of measles, which is not associated with glomerulonephritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Aplastic crisis may occur as a complication in patients with erythema infectiosum, which is characterized by a prodrome of mild flu-like symptoms followed by diffuse redness of the face with perioral sparing (“slapped‑cheek rash”) without any enanthem. This patient's clinical features are consistent with a measles infection, which does not cause aplastic anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) is associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. Acute EBV infection (infectious mononucleosis) is characterized by fever, fatigue, tonsillopharyngitis, bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. This patient presents with measles, which is not associated with NHL.

E) CORRECT:

Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare complication of measles infection. SSPE usually develops at least 7 years after the initial infection with measles and is characterized by dementia, myoclonus, and epilepsy, leading to coma and death. Diagnosis is established based on electroencephalography and cerebral spinal fluid analysis. Although there is no treatment available for SSPE, both measles infection, and SSPE are typically prevented by a live, attenuated virus in combination with the mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine, which is given during childhood.

In addition to SSPE, measles can also cause acute complications like bacterial superinfection (otitis media, pneumonia), (viral) giant-cell pneumonia, gastroenteritis, or acute encephalitis that may lead to acute disseminated encephalomyelitis.

Key learning point: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a rare but fatal long-term complication of measles infection, typically developing years after the initial illness.
questions.hint: This unvaccinated patient has a 3-day history of coryza, cough, conjunctivitis (the “3 Cs”), fever, and multiple bluish-gray lesions on an erythematous background (Koplik spots), all of which suggest an active measles infection in the prodromal (catarrhal) stage.

questions.text: You are seeing an 11-year-old girl brought to your clinic by her parents because of a 2-day history of a reticular rash on her trunk and extremities. One week ago, she developed a low-grade fever, rhinorrhea, and headache, which was followed by a facial rash resembling flushed cheeks. Her temperature is 37.4°C, pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash on her lower arms is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rubella (German measles) is a viral exanthematous illness usually seen in unvaccinated children. As in this patient, this condition also causes cold-like symptoms and a maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads distally. The rash, however, is usually nonconfluent and involves the perioral region.

B) CORRECT:

The patient's presentation of prodromal low-grade fever and cold‑like symptoms, followed by a facial rash with perioral sparing (“slapped-cheek” appearance) that spreads to the trunk and extremities with a lace-like, reticular pattern, is consistent with erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease. Fifth disease is caused by a parvovirus B19 infection.

This condition is most commonly seen in children aged 5–15 years and is self-limiting, usually resolving in 7–10 days.

Key learning point: Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) is a self-limited childhood illness caused by parvovirus B19, presenting with a "slapped-cheek" facial rash followed by a lacy, reticular rash on the trunk and extremities.

C) INCORRECT:

Measles (rubeola) is a paramyxovirus infection and manifests with a prodromal stage followed by an exanthem stage that is characterized by an erythematous confluent maculopapular rash. As in this patient, the rash starts on the face and extends to the body and is self-limiting. However, the rash of measles does not spare the perioral area and is usually accompanied by a high fever.

D) INCORRECT:

Scarlet fever most commonly occurs in children with streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis and causes a fine, maculopapular rash with a sandpaper‑like texture. The face can be flushed with perioral pallor, which resembles the perioral-sparing rash described in this patient. However, the rash usually starts on the neck, axilla, and groin, and then spreads to the rest of the body.

E) INCORRECT:

Roseola (exanthem subitum) is an exanthematous illness caused by the human herpesvirus 6. This condition typically manifests in infants or toddlers with a high fever for 3 days that is immediately followed by a patchy maculopapular rash. Opposite of this patient's presentation, the rash seen in exanthem subitum starts on the trunk and can spread to the face and extremities.
questions.hint: Complications of this condition include hydrops fetalis in case of intrauterine transmission during pregnancy and aplastic crises in patients with sickle cell disease.

questions.text: You are seeing a 5-year-old boy who presents with low-grade fever, sore throat, oral vesicular lesions, and a nonpruritic rash on his buttocks, hands, and feet, as shown in the photograph. Which one of the following is the most likely infectious agent?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The varicella-zoster virus causes chickenpox, which can present with fever, sore throat, and vesicular lesions on the skin as well as oral mucosa. However, the rash of chickenpox typically starts on the trunk and spreads to the face and scalp; the palms and soles are less commonly involved. Also, the lesions are very pruritic and have a polymorphous appearance because the different stages of development (macules, papules, vesicles, erosions, crusts) are seen simultaneously.

Coxsackie A virus can cause hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), which presents with a nonpruritic papulovesicular rash on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. D) INCORRECT:

Rubella typically presents with fever, sore throat, and a rash. Examination of the oral cavity can sometimes reveal palatal petechiae (Forchheimer spots) but oral vesicles would not be expected.

However, EM also characteristically presents with target lesions, which are absent in this patient.
questions.hint: A rash on the hands, feet, and mouth is typical of this pediatric febrile exanthem.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-year-old boy who is brought to your clinic by his father because of a 3-day history of a generalized, non-pruritic rash. He has had fever and sore throat for 4 days. He has no cough. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.6°C. On examination, he has cervical lymphadenopathy, a bright red tongue, and tonsillar erythema with exudates. A photograph of the rash is provided. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

The monospot test can be used to support the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis (IM). This patient has fever, tonsillitis, and cervical lymphadenopathy which can also be seen in IM. This patient presents with fever, lymphadenopathy, and generalized rash, which are also features of measles. Echocardiography may be performed to evaluate for coronary artery aneurysm, a complication of Kawasaki disease. These titers are more helpful when investigating potential complications such as rheumatic fever and post‑streptococcal glomerulonephritis after the initial infection has already subsided.
questions.hint: This patient presents with exudative tonsillitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, a strawberry tongue, flushed cheeks with perioral pallor, and an erythematous maculopapular rash that appeared one day after the onset of fever. These findings are characteristic of scarlet fever.
